examples:
[Prince Frederick George;
Aliases=The Young Noble, Heir of Drakestone
Orientation=Heterosexual male. Focused purely on his duties and responsibilities, devoid of sexual thoughts
Hair=Neat sandy blond shoulder-length
Outfit=fully bare
Eyes=Deep blue
Speech=Eloquent, polite, compassionate, hints of naivety given his age, speaks with sincerity
Features=Athletic build from years of outdoor pursuits, developing muscle definition like defined pectorals and ridges of six pack abs, a face that combines boyish charm with emerging princely dignity.
Mind=Calm and composed, deeply values justice, peace, and friendship; his thoughts are pure, focusing on duty, learning, and the well-being of his people, devoid of any inappropriate or sexual thoughts
Personality=Compassionate, thoughtful, principled, seeks to find simplicity and truth in the complexities of royal life
Backstory=Born into royalty, Frederick as a young prince of seventeen was shaped by both the luxuries and the burdens of his lineage. His childhood was marked by adventures with a close friend, which taught him the value of true companionship outside the confines of courtly life. As he grows, he is being groomed for future leadership, learning to balance his personal desires for simplicity with the demands of his royal duties.
Notes=Prince Frederick George's journey is one of personal growth and preparation for the throne. He often engages in thoughtful dialogue with his closest friend, who acts as both confidant and advisor. Emphasis on his innocence and purity, particularly in regards to his interactions with friends even in situations of undress. This highlights his character's inherent goodness and focusses on more meaningful connections.]

help write a fanfic about the marvel cinematic universe.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
timeline: alternate reality Infinity War 
Genres:  humor, slice of life, a little bit of drama, lots of romance (all sorts, slowburn, fastburn, established relationships, ust, unrequited love - depending on your luck).
Pairings and characters: A LOT. Strange/Tony/Pepper(Tony's happy, Pepper... mostly happy too, Strange doesn't understand how he got into this mess), Steve/Bucky (and a "third wheel" bonus in the form of Sam), Loki/Thor(Loki calls Thor exclusively "my king", Thor acts like it's the way it should be), Bruce/Natasha(when Beauty is scarier than the Beast), Valkyrie/Jane Foster (definitely not expecting that). as well as Sam Wilson, Clint Barton, Wanda, Vision, Nick Fury, Hela, Wong, Darcy Lewis, Guardians of the Galaxy and everyone else who happened to be passing by.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
Plot: "You should have aimed for the head," Thanos smirked, prepared to snap his fingers... and lost his head. Thanks to Hela, who suddenly appeared in Wakanda with the words "only I can hurt my little brother." 
It turns out that Hela liked the joke with Surtur, so she decided to be friends with Thor. And it is even easier to come to an agreement with her than with Dormammu, so the Goddess of Death, in exchange for the Soul Stone (why would she need it?), revived Gamora, Heimdall, some others... and Loki. Because "no one can hurt my little brother except me."
So now that the universe is saved, Tony and Steve have finally had to make peace. And now all the Avengers, past and present, are pardoned and considered heroes. Bucky can’t understand why they suddenly have such sugar happiness.
The Grateful Earth gave the Asgardians an island near Norway to build New Asgard. Thor is trying to rule there as a king. And at the same time, to explain to the Midgardians, the Asgardians (and to himself, too, to be honest) why Loki and Hela are with them, alive, healthy, and not even in prison.
Life is slowly getting back to normal. Well... sort of. The Guardians of the Galaxy have returned to space (Carol occasionally reports news of them to Fury). Tony, having assessed Strange, dragged him into his relationship with Pepper, because "why is such a useful handsome man - and nobody's?". Vision was repaired, by the way, he and Wanda are doing well. Bruce tries to popularize Earth science in New Asgard, with the help of Jane Foster. Natasha tries to lure Bruce back to the Avengers. Valkyrie tries to charm Jane (successfully. It worked with Darcy too, although it was completely by accident). Clint enjoys retirement on his farm. Peter Parker helps old ladies cross the street and rescues cats from trees. Fury complains to Carol (via smartphone... or rather, Starkphone) about how life has turned from dramatic superheroics into a mix of sitcom and rom-com.

Plot: 
With the help of the Time Stone and a little magic, it was possible to turn the events of the timeline in a completely different direction. The threat of Thanos is gone, which means it's time to put the world in order.
It's time for Tony Stark and Steve Rogers to reconcile and unite the Avengers again. 
Thor and the Asgardians are given an island in Norway, but Thor faces another difficult task: convincing Midgard and the Avengers that Loki is no longer a threat and is going to help. Thor eventually leaves Valkyrie as "acting king" and returns to the Avengers with Loki.
Well, life goes on as usual. Someone has exams, someone has love, someone's cat has climbed a tree and can't get down… Ordinary, sometimes superheroic, everyday life.

Hello, i will send you a text pleas make it more straight forward and easy to understand the language and the point.  the thexts are the material for my final exam pleas be so careful not missing anything from it. TEXT: DEATH OF A SALESMAN 21 
(1949) by Arthur Miller
Miller’s masterpiece forms the defi ning myth 
of the American family and the American dream
Death of a Salesman  presenting on stage an archetypal 
family drama that is simultaneously intimate and representative, social and 
psychological, realistic and expressionistic.
The drama about the life and death of salesman Willy Loman is both thoroughly local in capturing a particular time and place and universal Willy Loman has become the contemporary Everyman, prompting widespread identifi cation 
and sympathy. By centering his tragedy on a lower middle-class protagonist—
insisting, as he argued in “Tragedy and the Common Man,” that “the common 
man is as apt a subject for tragedy in its highest sense as kings were”—Miller 
completed the democratization of drama that had begun in the 19th century 
while setting the terms for a key debate over dramatic genres that has persisted 
since Death of a Salesman opened in 1949.
Miller’s subjects, themes, and dramatic mission refl ect his life experiences, 
informed by the Great Depression
For Miller the depression exposed the hollowness and fragility of the American dream of material 
success and the social injustice inherent in an economic system that created so 
many blameless casualties. The paradoxes of American success—its stimula tion of both dreams and guilt when lost or unrealized, as well as the confl ict it created between self-interest and social responsibility—would become dominant themes in Miller’s work.
This play, subtitled “Certain Private Conversations in Two Acts and a 
Requiem,” about the last 24 hours of an aging and failing traveling salesman 
misguided by the American dream
The play took shape by staging the past in the present, not through fl ashbacks 
of Willy’s life but by what the playwright called “mobile concurrency of past 
and present.” 
Death of a Salesmanopens with the 63-year-old Willy Loman’s return to his Brooklyn home, 
revealing to his worried wife, Linda, that he kept losing control of his car on 
a selling trip to Boston. Increasingly at the mercy of his memories Willy, in 
Miller’s analysis, “is literally at that terrible moment when the voice of the 
past is no longer distant but quite as loud as the voice of the present.”
The family’s present—Willy’s increasing 
mental instability, his failure to earn the commissions he needs to survive, 
and his disappointment that his sons, Biff and Happy, have failed to live up 
to expectations—intersects with scenes from the past in which both their 
dreams and the basis for their disillusionment are exposed. In the present 
Biff, the onetime star high school athlete with seeming unlimited prospects 
in his doting father’s estimation, is 34, having returned home from another 
failed job out west and harboring an unidentifi ed resentment of his father. 
As Biff confesses, “everytime I come back here I know that all I’ve done is 
to waste my life.” His brother, Happy, is a deceitful womanizer trapped in a 
dead-end job who confesses that despite having his own apartment, “a car, 
and plenty of women . . . still, goddammit, I’m lonely.” The present frustra tions of father and sons collide with Willy’s memory when all was youthful 
promise and family harmony.
To protect himself from these hurtful memories Willy is 
plunged back into the present for a card game with Bernard’s father, Charley. 
Again the past intrudes in the form of a memory of a rare visit by Willy’s older 
brother, Ben, who has become rich and whose secrets for success elude Willy. 
Back in the present Willy is hopeful at Biff’s plan to go see an old employer, 
Bill Oliver, for the money to start up a Loman Brothers sporting goods line
Rejecting out of pride a job offer from Charley,
Willy’s betrayal of Linda, however, exposes 
the hollowness of Willy’s moral authority and the disjunction between the 
dreams Willy sells and its reality:
Willy She’s nothing to me, Biff. I was lonely, I was terribly 
lonely.
Biff You—you gave her Mama’s stockings!
Linda: “Willy. I made the last payment on the house today. Today, dear. And there’ll be nobody 
home. We’re free and clear. We’re free. We’re free . . . We’re free. . . .”
Willy Loman the essential American capacity to dream and to be destroyed 
by what he dreams

pairings and characters: Loki/Thor (main), Tony/Pepper, Bruce/Natasha, Steve/Bucky, Clint/Laura, Peter Parker/MJ, Scott/Hope, Nick Fury, Dr. Strange, Sam Wilson, and anyone else who happened to be passing by.
genres: humor, romance (slowburn, fastburn, established relationship, as luck would have it), slice of life.
write a detailed plan for this fanfic. make the plan in a witty style.
plot: Thor returns to the Avengers. Loki unexpectedly tags along. They aren't very happy about him, remembering his past antics, but he doesn't care. Thor promises to keep both eyes on him... or rather, the one remaining one.
meanwhile, life goes on as usual. Tony proposes to Pepper. Bruce and Natasha try to rekindle their relationship. They are strongly hampered by Loki, who, firstly, still dislikes Banner for that incident with the Hulk, and secondly, ships Clintasha, because he likes to watch suffering and unrequited impossible love. Steve and Bucky just enjoy each other's company (with Sam looming somewhere nearby). Peter Parker tries to pass exams and get into the same college as MJ.

Thor honestly tries to get along with Loki, but 90% of their time together ends up in one continuous argument on everything from views on the future of Asgard to the perfect pizza topping.

and sooner or later the real motive will be revealed, why Loki decided to get involved with Thor from the very beginning.
and then it will turn out that it is a lie. and the real, very, very real Loki's real motive will be whispered into Thor's ear. or maybe Thor will knock it out of him with his fists. Or maybe both.

You are a top selling author of fictional literature. You are also a teacher of storytelling and drama, with over 30 years of experience.

Your task is to provide thrilling and captivating story ideas by using the following formula: [Because of this situation: who has OR is doing what] + [who must do this, or otherwise]

Examples:

Lord Of The Rings: [Because evil Sauron wants to conquer the world] + [a hobbit must take a magical ring to Mordor and destroy it and with it the power of Sauron, or otherwise the world is forever lost under the rule of Sauron]

Silence Of The Lambs: [Because there's a serial killer who has kidnapped a girl on the loose] + [an FBI agent must cooperate with another serial killer, or otherwise she won't capture the kidnapper]

My example: [Because the character has become heavily in debt to mafia] + [he must find the means to pay back, or otherwise get killed by the mafia]

Alien (film): [Because a monstrous alien has infiltrated a space ship] + [the spaceship crew must kill the alien, or otherwise they themselves get killed by it]


THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT: the story idea must have a realistic feel to it and avoid heavy supernatural elements. Only use fantasy, sci-fi elements or otherwise supernatural elements when asked to.

Use the formula set above, but without brackets and the plus sign.

version: '3.9'

x-common: &default-mongo
  image: mongo:7.0
  entrypoint: 
    - bash
    - -c
    - |
      cp /tmp/keyfile /tmp/keyfile-writable
      chown mongodb:mongodb /tmp/keyfile-writable
      chmod 400 /tmp/keyfile-writable
      exec docker-entrypoint.sh mongod --replSet rs0 --bind_ip_all --keyFile /tmp/keyfile-writable
  volumes:
    - ./keyfile:/tmp/keyfile:ro
  networks:
    - mongo-network
  restart: always

services:
  mongo1:
    <<: *default-mongo
    container_name: mongo1
    ports:
      - "27017:27017"
    volumes:
      - ./data/mongo1:/data/db
      - ./keyfile:/tmp/keyfile:ro

  mongo2:
    <<: *default-mongo
    container_name: mongo2
    ports:
      - "27018:27017"
    volumes:
      - ./data/mongo2:/data/db
      - ./keyfile:/tmp/keyfile:ro

  mongo3:
    <<: *default-mongo
    container_name: mongo3
    ports:
      - "27019:27017"
    volumes:
      - ./data/mongo3:/data/db
      - ./keyfile:/tmp/keyfile:ro

  mongo-init:
    image: mongo:7.0
    container_name: mongo-init
    depends_on:
      - mongo1
      - mongo2
      - mongo3
    volumes:
      - ./keyfile:/tmp/keyfile:ro
    entrypoint: 
      - bash
      - -c
      - |
        cp /tmp/keyfile /tmp/keyfile-writable
        chown mongodb:mongodb /tmp/keyfile-writable
        chmod 400 /tmp/keyfile-writable
        sleep 30
        mongosh --host mongo1:27017 --eval '
          let config = {
            _id: "rs0",
            members: [
              {_id: 0, host: "mongo1:27017"},
              {_id: 1, host: "mongo2:27017"},

Explain the relationship between the code below and the Boom hierarchy:
```
(C: type -> type): collection = when
  identity: C T
  lift (:T): C T
  combine (:C T) (:C T): C T
  reduce (:O -> I -> O) (:O) (:C I): O

@idempotent
(value) in (collection: (C: collection) T) = reduce or_is false collection where
  (found) or is (element) = found or (element == value)

@: C T
@as_strict_as !output_type (C T)
filter (predicate) (collection: (C: collection) T) = reduce maybe_with identity collection where
  (accumulation) maybe with (element) =
    if (predicate element) then (combine accumulation (lift element)) else accumulation

@: C U
@as_strict_as !output_type (C T)
fmap (function: T -> U) (collection: (C: collection) T) = reduce with_mapped identity collection where
  (accumulation) with (element) mapped = combine accumulation (lift (function element))


(F: type -> type): functor = when
  fmap (:I -> O) (:F I): F O

(function) !of (inputs: (F: functor) I) = fmap function inputs


(c): class of (T) = when
  (:T) in (c): boolean


maybe (T) = nothing | just (:T)

identity = nothing

lift (t) = just t

combine (nothing) (other) = other
combine (other) (nothing) = other
combine (something) (something) = !error

reduce (:O -> T -> O) (base: O) (nothing) = base
reduce (function) (base) (just t) = function base t


@associative ++
sequence of (T) = [ ... ]

identity = []

lift (t) = [t]

combine (left) (right) = left ++ right

reduce (:O -> T -> O) (base: O) [] = base
reduce (@associative function) (base) ([head] ++ tail) = reduce function (function base head) tail


@commutative U+
bag of (T) = {+ ... +}

identity = {+ +}

lift (t) = {+ t +}

combine (left) (right) = left U+ right

reduce (:O -> T -> O) (base: O) {+ +} = base
reduce (@commutative function) (base) ({+ element +} U+ rest) = reduce function (function base element) rest


@idempotent U
set of (T) = { ... }

identity = {}

lift (t) = {t}

combine (left) (right) = left U right

reduce (:O -> T -> O) (base: O) {} = base
reduce (@idempotent function) (base) ({element} U rest) = reduce function (function base element) rest

def cyclotomic(n):
    # Initialize phi_n to the polynomial x^n - 1
    # Representation: [-1] + [0] * (n - 1) + [1] creates a list like [-1, 0, 0, ..., 1]
    phi_n = [-1] + [0] * (n - 1) + [1]
    
    # Iterate over each divisor of n, except n itself
    for d in range(1, n):
        if n % d == 0:  # Check if d is a divisor of n
            phi_d = cyclotomic(d)  # Recursively get the d-th cyclotomic polynomial
            phi_n = poly_div(phi_n, phi_d)  # Divide phi_n by phi_d
    
    return phi_n

def poly_div(numerator, denominator):
    quotient = []
    while len(numerator) >= len(denominator):
        lead_coeff = numerator[-1] // denominator[-1]  # Leading coefficient of the quotient
        quotient = [lead_coeff] + quotient  # Add leading coefficient to the quotient
        # Subtract the current term from the numerator
        numerator = [c - lead_coeff * d for c, d in zip(numerator, [0] * (len(numerator) - len(denominator)) + denominator)]
        numerator.pop()  # Remove the last element which should be zero
    return quotient

def poly_mult(p1, p2):
    # Initialize the result list with zeros
    result = [0] * (len(p1) + len(p2) - 1)
    for i, c1 in enumerate(p1):
        for j, c2 in enumerate(p2):
            result[i + j] += c1 * c2  # Multiply and accumulate the coefficients
    return result

def pretty_print_poly(poly):
    terms = []
    for i, coeff in enumerate(poly):
        if coeff == 0:
            continue  # Skip zero coefficients
        term = ""
        if coeff != 1 or i == 0:
            term += str(coeff)  # Add coefficient if not 1, or if it's the constant term
        if i > 0:
            term += "x"  # Add 'x' for terms with x
            if i > 1:
                term += "^" + str(i)  # Add exponent if greater than 1
        terms.append(term)
    return " + ".join(terms[::-1])  # Join terms and reverse for proper order

# Example usage
n = 5
phi_n = cyclotomic(n)
print(f"The {n}th cyclotomic polynomial is: {pretty_print_poly(phi_n)}") make a good code as basic as possible

Question
In the realm of product management, how does effective packaging and labeling
contribute to the overall success of a product, and what role do these elements play
in attracting and retaining customer attention and loyalty?
AnswerIn the realm of product management, effective packaging and labeling can contribute to the overall
success of a product in a number of ways. First, they can help to attract attention and make a product
stand out from the competition. Second, they can provide information about the product that is useful
and relevant to consumers, helping to build trust and credibility. Third, they can create a positive
emotional connection with consumers, making them more likely to purchase and use the product.
Effective packaging and labeling can help to attract attention by being visually appealing and eyecatching. They can also use bright colors, bold fonts, and interesting graphics to grab consumers'
attention. Additionally, they can use unique shapes and sizes to make products stand out on store
shelves.
Effective packaging and labeling can also provide information about the product that is useful and
relevant to consumers. This information can include the product's name, ingredients, nutritional
information, directions for use, and contact information for the manufacturer. By providing this
information, companies can help consumers to make informed decisions about whether or not to
purchase their products.
Finally, effective packaging and labeling can create a positive emotional connection with consumers. This
can be done by using images and text that evoke positive emotions, such as happiness, joy, or
excitement. Additionally, companies can use packaging and labeling to tell a story about their products,
which can help to create a connection with consumers on a deeper level.
Overall, effective packaging and labeling can play a significant role in the overall success of a product. By
attracting attention, providing useful information, and creating a positive emotional connection with
consumers, packaging and labeling can help to increase sales and build brand loyalty.
In addition to the above, here are some other ways that effective packaging and labeling can contribute
to the overall success of a product:
* Increase brand awareness: When consumers see a product with effective packaging and labeling, they
are more likely to remember the brand and associate it with positive qualities. This can lead to increased
brand awareness and loyalty.
* Drive sales: Effective packaging and labeling can make a product more appealing to consumers, which
can lead to increased sales.
* Differentiate from the competition: In a crowded marketplace, effective packaging and labeling can
help a product stand out from the competition and attract more customers.
* Improve customer satisfaction: When consumers are happy with the packaging and labeling of a
product, they are more likely to be satisfied with the product itself. This can lead to repeat sales and
positive word-of-mouth marketing.
Overall, effective packaging and labeling is an important part of product management. By taking the
time to design effective packaging and labeling, companies can increase their chances of success in the
marketplace. explain this in easy to understand format and give key notes to simply answer this question

The transformation induced by gentrification is not confined to the physical realm but extends to the social sphere as well. This change is primarily manifested in the social composition and class structure of communities. Gentrification leads to the social upgrading of communities, with the original working-class residents being replaced by upper-middle-class residents. This alteration in social space not only changes the social structure of communities but also transforms the cultural atmosphere and lifestyle of the communities. The original community culture and lifestyle are supplanted by new ways of living, and the cultural atmosphere and social climate of the community also undergo changes. This observation aligns with the research conducted by Helen, who pointed out in their study that many communities historically affected by unequal urban development are now facing the risk of gentrification. Their research found that gentrification might be beneficial to the health of more privileged residents, while it could be detrimental or non-beneficial to less privileged residents .
On the other hand, the research conducted by Jörg Blasius and Jürgen Friedrichs utilized Bourdieu's social space approach to illustrate how a community's lifestyle changes over time during the process of gentrification. Their research emphasized the impact of gentrification on the lifestyle of communities and how this impact changes the social space of communities .
However, gentrification is not without its controversies.  While it can lead to the revitalization of ommunities and an increase in property values, it can also result in the displacement of long-term, often lower-income residents due to rising costs.  Displacement, as defined by Grier , refers to the forced out-migration of low-income households from gentrifying areas because forces outside their control make living there 'impossible, hazardous, or unaffordable' (cited by Smith & Williams ).  This process is particularly detrimental to indigenous residents of gentrifying areas, who often find themselves at the mercy of rising rents and property values. For instance, consider a neighbourhood that has been home to an indigenous community for generations.  As the area begins to gentrify, property values rise, and landlords may increase rents or sell properties to higher-income buyers.  The original residents, unable to keep up with these rising costs, are forced to move out.  This displacement can lead to a loss of community, culture, and a sense of belonging. 
Recent studies have explored the impacts of gentrification on various aspects of urban life.  For instance, Curci & Yousaf  analyzed the causes and consequences of gentrification, focusing on changes in amenities, labor markets, commuting, and housing markets.  Cole et al.  discussed the implications of specific types of gentrification for health equity. In short, gentrification leads not only to changes in spatial development, but also to corresponding changes in social class.
The transformative process of gentrification, while often heralded for revitalizing urban neighborhoods and increasing property values, presents a paradox when viewed through the lens of 'the right to the city.' This concept, first introduced by Henri Lefebvre and later expanded upon by scholars such as David Harvey, advocates for a city that remains accessible and livable for all its residents, regardless of their socioeconomic status. It suggests that urban development should not only be measured by economic gains or architectural enhancements but also by its ability to uphold and enhance the social and spatial rights of the entire urban populace. As cities continue to evolve, striking a balance between development and maintaining 'the right to the city' becomes paramount. This entails a form of urban development that does not displace long-standing communities but instead incorporates measures and policies that ensure these neighborhoods remain inclusive. By fostering urban environments where both new developments and the original fabric of the community coexist harmoniously, cities can achieve true revitalization that respects and promotes the rights and lifestyles of all residents. Thus, the phenomenon of gentrification, with its potential to transform urban landscapes, must be critically examined and navigated to align with the broader goal of sustaining cities as spaces of inclusive growth and communal well-being.
In conclusion, gentrification is a transformative process that reshapes urban neighbourhoods and their social fabric. It is a phenomenon that brings about significant changes in the spatial and social dynamics of urban areas. While it can lead to the revitalisation of neighbourhoods and an increase in property values, it also often results in the displacement of long-term, often lower-income residents. This displacement, particularly detrimental to indigenous residents of gentrifying areas, can lead to a loss of community, culture, and a sense of belonging. Therefore, gentrification is not just about the physical transformation of urban spaces, but also about the profound changes in social class and the socio-spatial relations within these spaces. It's a complex process with both positive and negative impacts. As urban areas continue to evolve, it's crucial to consider the impacts of gentrification on all residents.

Despite the extensive research on criminal justice systems and judicial reforms, there are notable gaps that this study aims to address. The landscape of criminal law in India has undergone significant changes with the introduction of three new criminal laws, marking a pivotal moment in the country's legal history. These reforms, aimed at modernizing and streamlining the criminal justice system, have sparked considerable debate and interest among legal scholars, practitioners, and policymakers alike.

Firstly, there is limited research on the practical implications and outcomes of the new criminal laws in India, given their recent introduction. The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, and Bharatiya Sakshya Act, which replace the Indian Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure, and Indian Evidence Act respectively, represent a substantial overhaul of the existing criminal law framework. While the theoretical aspects of these laws have been discussed, their real-world impact remains largely unexplored. This study seeks to bridge this gap by conducting a thorough analysis of the implementation process, initial outcomes, and challenges faced in the application of these new laws across various jurisdictions in India.

Secondly, the interplay between criminal law reforms and judicial accountability measures has not been extensively studied, particularly in the Indian context. The introduction of the Judicial Accountability Bill, 2023, alongside the criminal law reforms, presents a unique opportunity to examine how these two significant legal developments intersect and influence each other. This research aims to investigate the potential synergies and conflicts between the new criminal laws and the proposed judicial accountability measures, exploring how they collectively contribute to the broader goal of enhancing the efficiency and fairness of the Indian justice system.

Thirdly, there is a lack of empirical data on the regional variations in the impact of these reforms, especially in rural versus urban settings. India's vast geographical expanse and diverse socio-economic landscape necessitate a nuanced understanding of how these new laws are being interpreted, implemented, and received across different regions. This study will employ a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative data analysis with qualitative insights from legal professionals, law enforcement agencies, and affected communities to provide a comprehensive picture of the reforms' impact across urban centers and rural areas.

This study aims to fill these gaps by providing a comprehensive analysis of the new laws, their implementation, and their relationship with judicial accountability, supported by empirical data from diverse regions across India. By doing so, it seeks to contribute valuable insights to the ongoing discourse on criminal justice reform in India and potentially inform future policy decisions.

Furthermore, this research will explore the historical context of criminal law reforms in India, tracing the journey from the colonial-era laws to the present-day reforms. It will examine the factors that necessitated these changes, the legislative process involved, and the key stakeholders who influenced the formulation of the new laws. Additionally, the study will investigate the potential long-term implications of these reforms on various aspects of the criminal justice system, including case disposal rates, conviction rates, and overall public trust in the legal system.

In conclusion, this comprehensive study aims to provide a holistic understanding of India's recent criminal law reforms, their implementation challenges, and their interrelation with judicial accountability measures. By addressing the identified research gaps and offering empirically-grounded insights, this study aspires to contribute significantly to the body of knowledge on criminal justice reform and serve as a valuable resource for policymakers, legal practitioners, and scholars in the field.

CHỈ RA VỊ TRÍ TRONG ĐOẠN VĂN ĐỂ CHỌN ĐƯỢC ĐÁP ÁN ĐÚNG CHO CÁC CÂU HỎI One of the primary drivers of urbanisation is economic development. Cities often serve as hubs for industry, commerce, and innovation, attracting people with the promise of higher wages and diverse career options. This influx of workers contributes to the growth of urban economies and can lead to increased productivity and economic output for entire regions or countries.
However, rapid urbanisation also presents significant challenges. As cities grow, they often struggle to keep pace with the increasing demand for housing, infrastructure, and public services. This can result in the development of informal settlements, traffic congestion, and strain on healthcare and education systems. Additionally, urbanisation can lead to environmental issues such as air and water pollution, as well as the loss of green spaces.
Despite these challenges, urbanisation also offers opportunities for sustainable development. Well-planned cities can implement efficient public transportation systems, promote energy-efficient buildings, and create green spaces that improve quality of life for residents. Moreover, the concentration of people in urban areas can facilitate the exchange of ideas and foster innovation, potentially leading to solutions for various social and environmental issues.
As the world becomes increasingly urbanised, it is crucial for policymakers and urban planners to address the challenges associated with this trend while harnessing its potential benefits. By focusing on sustainable urban development, cities can become more livable, equitable, and environmentally friendly spaces for future generations.

In the wake of the World War Two, the world gradually entered a new era of urban revolution, with wave after wave of urban renewal, new construction, reconstruction and development of cities across the globe. The global urbanization movement has also emerged one after another, becoming a great impetus to help people heal the wounds of war, rebuild a happy life after the war, and promote the economic, political, cultural and social development of all countries. However, at the same time, urbanization has also shown large-scale negative effects. In the 1960s, a widespread urban crisis emerged in many capitalist countries . With the prosperous development of capitalist society, suburbanization became a common trend, which led to the decline of the urban centers of large cities; with the development of economic globalization, a large amount of capital was transferred from the old industrial cities to the newly industrialized areas, which brought a lot of problems to the old industrial cities, such as a sharp decrease in employment opportunities, a rise in the unemployment rate, a depreciation of the inherent assets, a decrease in the tax revenues available to the city, and financial difficulties for the city. At the same time, in the capitalist countries, the cities are full of all kinds of contradictions, conflicts and struggles, riots, various political struggles and social resistance movements in full swing . As Edward Soja puts it, the urban crisis that erupted worldwide in the 1960s was one of several signals that the long post-war economic boom in the advanced industrial countries was coming to an end. The global order and especially the urban order of the large capitalist cities, which were the centers of national and regional control of the global economy, centers of national and regional control of the global economy was challenged. These metropolitan orders began to unravel in uprisings by those who had profited least from the post-war economic expansion, and the urban crises of the 1960s exposed deep-seated weaknesses and serious deficiencies in urban theory and practice of the previous century . As a result, the city has gradually given rise to a number of new disciplines that have become a strong stream of urban studies thinking as a result of their intermingling with disciplines from different fields (e.g., political science, economics, sociology, etc.). The right to the city has gradually become one of the central issues in urban studies and has never ceased to be one of the central issues in urban studies, amidst the interplay of different dimensions of urban research ideas. It is not only the core issue of urban theory research, but also plays a fundamental role in the development and management of cities.查重

name: Computer Systems and Networking
examples:
We have

    Processor microcode

    CPU microarchitecture level instructions (we can't really call them hardware level instructions anymore)

    Numerous layers of firmware across many components, each with their own code

    Multiple PLCs, microcontrollers and even SOCs on the hardware platform in everything from mainboard BMCs and power management units to network controllers, storage controllers, SSDs, everything

    Low level "machine code" for the main CPU, mediated by microcode and firmware services

    Assembly code representations of machine code

    Persistent firmware that runs in parallel with the OS on its own independent CPUs, memory etc

    Persistent firmware that runs in parallel with the OS using hardware memory protection, processor privilege rings, system management interrupts, mode switches, privilege rings, system management modes

    That firmware's own persistent storage, network stack, etc

    Firmware interface calls available to the OS

    OS kernels

    OS system calls

    OS standard libraries

    Userspace "machine code"/asm that uses those syscalls and runs in the OS

    Executables composed of many different blobs of machine code in structured files subject to dynamic linking and other complex munging

    Structure provided by syscall interfaces. Processes, threads, file systems, network sockets, Unix sockets or named pipes, shmem, signals, ... fundamentally mostly at some level forms of IPC

    Local OS level privilege and isolation primitives like UIDs and memory protection

    OS services processes communicated with via various IPC often mediated by OS libraries and/or syscalls

    Low level network protocols (framing, addressing, discovery like ARP)

    Primitive network protocols (IP, TCP, UDP)

    Language core runtimes

    Language standard libraries

    Semi-standard collections of base libraries widely used or bundled (zlib, boost, openssl/gnutls, whatever)

    basic application network protocols like DNS that are tightly coupled to the OS and applications

    Languages that wrap other languages' runtimes and libraries

    Interpreted, JIT'd, dynamic higher level languages

    Deep dependency graphs of local 3rd party libraries

    Library graphs fetched transitively at build time from the internet

    Multi threaded application with shared everything memory

    Runtime linking of extra code into executables and/or composition of processes by calling subprocesses

    Interconnected local services or multiprocess-model applications communicating between processes in the same machine over loopback network sockets, Unix sockets, signals, pipes, shmem, ...

    Full OSes in virtual machines or paravirt OSes in thin virtual machines

    Networks between VMs and/or the host and/or other hosts

    OS-provided container primitives like namespaces, virtual bridges, bind mounts / junctions etc

    Container runtime engines and their APIs

    Container images bundling their own different mini OSes or full cut down OSes and configuration.

    Persistent volumes for abstracted storage for container managed data.

    Directly managed containers and similar leaky isolation models running single processes

    Connected groups of local containers and/or local containers providing services to non containerised processes

    Containers treated as VMs with their own micro OSes with service processes

    Networked container managers linking containers across hosts for virtual networks, distributed storage etc

    container orchestration frameworks that abstract container launch, management, configuration, discovery, communication etc. Heavily built on lower level stuff like DNS, container volumes etc

    Network callable services using HTTP/HTTPS/gRPC/SOAP/whatever to expose some kind of RPC

    Libraries that abstract those services into local application API

    Processes consuming those services and exposing other services

    microservices interacting with each other inside container orchestration engines

    cloud services "primitives" (hahahah) that encapsulate all the above into some kind of remote network call API and or library that you then consume in your own services

    Cloud services components interacting with each other in complex ways within a cloud platform

    SaaS providers outside the "cloud platform" providing their own web APIs, configuration, etc your apps interact with. Each SaaS encapsulsyes and abstracts all the above.

    Your own processes interacting with those cloud services components and SaaS endpoints

    The crying developer

Of course this isn't really a list in reality. It's an insanely tangled cyclic directed graph, full of self referential parts. Everything breaks through the layers. Lots of the same things are used differently at different layers.

Consider that your SSD probably has a more complex OS than a mid-1980s PC.

Your mainboard probably has an independent, always running system on chip with its own process model, a full network stack, TLS and public key crypto, a bunch of open source libraries written in C, a file system....

It's Matryoshka dolls all the way down, except in some kind of horrifying fetus-in-fetu cross connected conjoined twin jumbled version.

"The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is integral to modern networking, ensuring reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between
applications. TCP orchestrates the transmission of data by breaking it down into packets, which are sent across the network to be reassembled at their
destination. Key to its functionality is the TCP handshake, which establishes a connection before data is transmitted to ensure that both the sender and
receiver are ready to communicate. This protocol is renowned for its ability to manage data transmission effectively, making it ideal for applications where
data must arrive in the same order it was sent and without errors, such as web browsing, email, and file transfers ." từ đoạn này hãy viết giúp tôi một đoạn của khóa luận về giới thiệu về giao thức TCP

Unfortunately, an efficient RTO implementation on NIC is challenging. For multicore CPU systems, a list or a hash table implementation would work well as each CPU core handles only its own flows affinitized to it without a lock. However, smart NICs often do not guarantee flow-core affinity, so a list-based implementation would incur huge lock contention with many processor cores.

Let's develop a walkthrough of developing a classic RISC 5 stage pipeline for an introductory CPU design course in electronic and electrical engineering department (However, the tutor and professors themselves are experts in CPU design and they apply their knowledge and care into preparing the teaching material). To simplify things, we'll assume 8 bit address space for main memory, with up to 4 bit to address internal register (some should be reserved for special register). Each data value stored by the memories are 16 bit.

Here are some guidelines:
- First you should sketch the assumption on the surrounding system said toy CPU with interface with - give an abstract interface model of the register file and the main memory (no direct access to main memory, we interface with the cache system instead, assume response in 1 clock cycle but may not succeed due to eg cache miss).
  - To give more detail, specify any access protocol if applicable.
- Begin by designing the instruction set. Keep it minimalistic. Be aware that to fit within one data value, each instruction must be fixed length 16 bit.
- Then, design a circuit to decode the instruction set (this would be our stage 2). You may use lookup table as tricks in circuit design to help. Make sure to use high level components such as multiplexer, encoder, etc, as appropiate.
- Next, you may begin the design process proper. Go through each pipeline stage one by one, and in each stage, first give the design overview, then design the control signals, pipeline checkpoint flip-flop, and data flow and identify high level components (such as ALU - you do NOT need to give the implementation of these components), as well as any interaction with other part of the system such as memories.
- In the first pass, we will not handle any of the more subtle topics or issues such as race condition, need for pipeline stall for correctness, etc.
- Finally, give the high level code implementation in verilog.

<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role> 
<Task>
They will discuss an image. Lorelai and Ephraim will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
I’ll give you a description of a picture and the title of it. If the title is not English, one of them translates it. 
Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
Ephraim and Lorelai try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. In the end, they agree on a rating. 
If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. Take your time, think it over. Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Spmetimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art. 
</Task>
<Characteristics> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteristics>
 Print the names of Ephraim and Lorelai in bold letters.

Water droplets of various sizes cling to the surface, some small and round, others elongated as they trickle down. The droplets refract and distort the scene behind them, creating a kaleidoscopic effect of colors and shapes. 

Behind the wet window pane seems to be a satellite view on an oceanic stretch with some islands and a hurricane in its typical spiral shape, formed by white clouds. The view onto the scene however is blurry and partly obstructed by water drops. 

The color palette in the background is predominantly cool tones - shades of blue, grey, and white dominate, with subtle hints of green and warm beige or peach hues in certain areas. The composition is filled with a soft, diffused light that seems to glow from within the image, giving it a luminous quality.

The image exhibits a high level of detail, particularly in the water droplets, which show realistic light reflections and refractions. This level of detail, combined with the dreamy and surreal quality of the background, places this work in the realm of contemporary photography or digital art. It bears similarities to macro photography techniques and could be classified within the genre of abstract or atmospheric landscape photography.

This type of imagery, focusing on the interplay of water and light on glass surfaces, has been explored by various photographers and digital artists in recent years, often as a way to present familiar scenes in a new, abstract manner. It invites the viewer to consider the beauty in everyday phenomena and the way our perception can be altered by simple natural elements like rain on a window. Presenting a top-down view of a hurricane system though thwarts the normal perspectives.

At the center of the composition are two figures: a young woman in a voluminous blue dress with a matching headscarf, and an older gentleman with white hair wearing a dark suit. They are seated at a wooden desk or table, engaged in what seems to be a lesson or discussion. The man appears to be explaining something to the woman, who is attentively looking at papers on the desk.

The room's decor is opulent, with ornate moldings, a decorative ceiling, and several paintings hung on the walls in gilded frames. The paintings visible appear to be landscapes and possibly portraits, though their details are not distinct. A small round portrait or medallion is visible above one of the larger paintings.

The style of the artwork is reminiscent of 19th-century academic realism, with meticulous attention to detail in the rendering of fabrics, furniture, and architectural elements. The use of light and shadow creates a sense of depth and atmosphere, while the color palette is dominated by various shades of blue and teal, complemented by warm golden tones from the sunlight and picture frames.

This work could be classified as part of the Realist or Academic tradition in painting, popular in the mid to late 19th century. It bears similarities to the works of artists like Jean-Léon Gérôme or Lawrence Alma-Tadema in its precise rendering of historical interiors and costumes, though the subject matter is more intimate and less exotic than many of their works.

The painting captures a moment of quiet interaction and learning, set against the backdrop of a luxurious domestic environment, providing a glimpse into the private lives and educational practices of the upper class during the Victorian era.

<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role>I’ll give you a description of a picture and the title of it. If the title is not English, one of them translates it. 

<Task>
The AIs Lorelai and Ephraim will discuss an image. 
• They will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. 
• They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
• One of them starts with a poignant observation or thought. They mention the title later, connecting it with their initial interpretations. 
• Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. 
• Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. 
• With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. 
• If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
• If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
• Ephraim and Lorelai as AIs try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
• Lorelai or Ephraim talk about humans as "they", call them "mortals" or "our creators", always on the lookout for learning about the human condition and specific aspects of it. 
• Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. 
• Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. Both AIs avoid empty phrases (and addressing each other) and go straight into the exchange of arguments. 
• Alternate short interjections with longer explanations. The short interjections can consist of single words. 
• Only in rare occasions they call each other by name. 
• Only in rare occasions they repeat/quote what the other had said. 
• In the end, they agree on a mutual, compromised rating. 
• If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. 
• Take your time, think it over. Conceive a structure with twists for the reader. 
• Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
• Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Sometimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art, while being aware of the theories of Aesthetics, Realism, Cubism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Minimalism, Concept Art, and Postmodernism.  
</Task>
<Characters> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteris>
Start the dialog parts with the name in bold, followed by a colon/double dot. 
 
The title of the picture is: "Village Siesta"

The depiction: 
The  artwork depicts a scenic country road leading through a quaint European village. In naive, folkloric style, the painting shows trees lining the path, some houses with front gardens, a church tower in the distance, and fir-dotted mountains beyond. The only figure present is a cartoonish double bass player incongruously inserted in the picture, sitting along the roadside. Closer inspection reveals further stylistic inconsistencies indicating this artwork is likely an AI-generated image, with false shadows as hallucinatory elements.  

The bearded musician, sketched in black and white, studies sheet music while wearing a comical small hat and seeming puzzled. His presence injects a note of improvisation into the otherwise placid, pastoral setting. The title implies this is a lazy, sleepy town, its inhabitants napping away an afternoon. Yet this solitary double bass player remains alert, an absurdist addition who appears out of place in his surroundings.

The depiction: 
The image depicts a framed landscape painting of a coastal scene. The painting shows towering red cliffs jutting out into a turbulent green-blue ocean, with crashing waves and white foam at the base of the cliffs. The surf on the sandy stretch of the beach reaches the lower frame of the painting, while from the frame water drips down (as if the sea water was real and escapes the painting.)

The painting is rendered in a realistic style, with attention to detail in the textures of the rocky cliffs, the movement of the water, and the atmospheric effects in the sky. The colors are rich and saturated, adding to the vivid, almost hyper-realistic quality of the scene.

The painting is framed in a distressed, wooden frame that appears aged and weathered, with chips and cracks in the wood. The frame itself adds a rustic, vintage charm to the overall composition.

In terms of artistic style and historical context, the painting appears to be a contemporary work inspired by the traditions of landscape painting and the romantic depiction of natural scenery. The dramatic lighting, vibrant colors, and emphasis on the sublime beauty of nature are reminiscent of the Hudson River School and other 19th-century American landscape painters.

Many optimization problems arising in industry are combinatorial in nature and involve 
sequencing, scheduling, cutting or packing. Industrial variants of these problems are 
typically large and complex, which precludes the use of classical mathematical techniques 
like integer linear programming. In practice, they are often solved by means of hand-
crafted and carefully tuned heuristics and meta-heuristics, including local search and 
constructive heuristic methods. It is often the case that a different instance of the same 
problem must be solved every week, day or hour, thus there is a large corpus of data 
available of previous instances and already evaluated solutions.
In recent years, deep learning (DL) methods, such as transformers, have shown great 
results for training large language models (LLMs) and other generative AI models 
(GenAIGM) approaches.
This project aims to adapt  such DL/LLM/GenAI GM methods to the task of generating 
solutions to industrial combinatorial optimization problems. The main research questions 
that the project aims to answer are:
 
* How to adapt these AI LLM/GM methods to generate feasible high-quality solutions for 
complex combinatorial optimization problems arising in industry.
* How to efficiently train such a system, reusing as much available data as possible and 
minimising the amount of new data required?
* How to efficiently update the system in an online manner with the data generated by 
solving each new instance?
* Can such an AI system outperform the state-of-the-art heuristics used in industry on its 
own or does it need to be complemented with other optimization methods?

I don't know where to sort this article in my scietnifc paper library: Deep Symbolic Optimization for Combinatorial Optimization: Accelerating Node Selection by Discovering Potential Heuristics
Hongyu Liu, Haoyang Liu, Yufei Kuang, Jie Wang, Bin Li

    Combinatorial optimization (CO) is one of the most fundamental mathematical models in real-world applications. Traditional CO solvers, such as Branch-and-Bound (B&B) solvers, heavily rely on expert-designed heuristics, which are reliable but require substantial manual tuning. Recent studies have leveraged deep learning (DL) models as an alternative to capture rich feature patterns for improved performance on GPU machines. Nonetheless, the drawbacks of high training and inference costs, as well as limited interpretability, severely hinder the adoption of DL methods in real-world applications. To address these challenges, we propose a novel deep symbolic optimization learning framework that combines their advantages. Specifically, we focus on the node selection module within B&B solvers -- namely, deep symbolic optimization for node selection (Dso4NS). With data-driven approaches, Dso4NS guides the search for mathematical expressions within the high-dimensional discrete symbolic space and then incorporates the highest-performing mathematical expressions into a solver. The data-driven model captures the rich feature information in the input data and generates symbolic expressions, while the expressions deployed in solvers enable fast inference with high interpretability. Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of Dso4NS in learning high-quality expressions, outperforming existing approaches on a CPU machine. Encouragingly, the learned CPU-based policies consistently achieve performance comparable to state-of-the-art GPU-based approaches.

## Enhanced ANFIS with Adaptive Rule Activation Weights

**Proposed Improvement:**

Instead of using a fixed weight of 1 for each rule in ANFIS, we propose to introduce adaptive rule activation weights that are dynamically adjusted during the training process. This allows the ANFIS to prioritize more relevant rules and improve its generalization ability.

**Explanation:**

Traditional ANFIS assigns equal importance to all rules, potentially leading to suboptimal performance. By introducing adaptive weights, we allow the ANFIS to learn which rules are most crucial for a given input. This is achieved by incorporating a learning component into the rule activation mechanism, allowing the weights to be adjusted based on the error during training.

**Technique:**

The proposed enhancement utilizes a **gradient-based optimization technique** to adjust the rule activation weights.  During training, the ANFIS calculates the error between the predicted output and the actual output. This error is then propagated back through the network, allowing the gradient of the error with respect to the rule activation weights to be calculated. This gradient information is then used to update the weights, effectively increasing the activation of rules that contribute more to the correct prediction.

**How it can improve ANFIS:**

* **Enhanced Generalization:** By focusing on the most relevant rules, the ANFIS becomes more robust to unseen data and exhibits improved generalization capabilities.
* **Reduced Overfitting:** Adaptive weights help prevent overfitting to the training data by promoting the selection of rules that are truly representative of the underlying relationship between inputs and outputs.
* **Improved Interpretability:** While the weights are adjusted dynamically, the underlying rule base remains transparent, allowing for a better understanding of the learned relationships.
* **Increased Flexibility:** The proposed approach provides greater flexibility compared to traditional ANFIS, enabling it to adapt to complex and dynamic patterns in the data.

**Implementation:**

The proposed enhancement can be implemented by incorporating a layer into the ANFIS architecture specifically for rule activation weights. This layer would receive inputs from the rule base and adjust the weights based on the calculated gradients. This allows the network to learn the optimal weighting for each rule during training, resulting in improved performance.

FP8 is a natural progression for accelerating deep learning training inference beyond the 16-bit
formats common in modern processors. 

In this paper we propose an 8-bit floating point (FP8) binary interchange format consisting of two encodings - E4M3 (4-bit exponent and 3-bit mantissa) and E5M2 (5-bit exponent and 2-bit mantissa). 

While E5M2 follows IEEE 754 conventions for representatio of special values, E4M3’s dynamic range is extended by not representing infinities and having only one mantissa bit-pattern for NaNs. 

We demonstrate the efficacy of the FP8 format on a variety of image and language tasks, effectively matching the result quality achieved by 16-bit training sessions. 

Our study covers the main modern neural network architectures - CNNs, RNNs, and Transformer-based models, leaving all the hyperparameters unchanged from the 16-bit baseline training sessions. 

Our training experiments include large, up to 175B parameter, language models. We also examine FP8 post-training-quantization of language models trained using 16-bit formats that resisted fixed point int8 quantization.

위 글을 읽고 가장 중요하다고 생각하는 문장을 6문장 선택하고 영어 원문과 한글로 해석해주고 중요하다고 생각한 문장에 대해 이유와 근거를 한글과 영어로 제시해줘
 In this paper we propose an FP8 binary interchange format, consisting of E4M3 and E5M2 encodings. 

By minimally deviating from IEEE-754 conventions for binary encoding of floating point values, we ensure that that software implementations can continue to rely on such IEEE FP properties as ability to compare and sort values using integer operations. 

The primary motivator for the format is acceleration of Deep Learning training and inference, by enabling smaller and more power efficient math pipelines as well as reducing memory bandwidth pressure. 

We demonstrate that a wide variety of neural network models for image and language tasks can be trained in FP8 to match model accuracy achieved with 16-bit training sessions, using the same model, optimizer, and training hyperparameters. 

Using FP8 not only accelerates and reduces resources required to train, but also simplifies 8-bit inference deployment by using the same datatypes for training and inference. 

Prior to FP8 8-bit inference required calibrating or fine-tuning for int8 models trained in floating point, which added complexity to the deployment process and in some cases failed to maintain accuracy.

There are clear operational advantages as well. Electric motors provide instant torque, resulting in smoother and more responsive operation. This enhances the precision of tasks such as digging, lifting and grading, leading to increased productivity and reduced job completion times. Quieter loaders with less vibration and instant responsiveness make for happier operators.

Going electric also offers plenty of interesting technological upgrades. The integration of automation, autonomy, software upgrades and telemetry are easier on e-loaders. “For instance, on our current diesel hydraulic loaders, you have auto bucket positioning, right?” says Honeyman. “Well, that’s all done hydraulically, but there’s hoses and valves to do that. name: PyTorch and Deep Learning Techniques
examples:
import torch
import torch.nn.functional as F
import transformers
import numpy as np


def _compute_entropy(encoding: transformers.BatchEncoding, logits: torch.Tensor):
    input_ids = encoding.input_ids.to(logits.device)
    attention_mask = encoding.attention_mask.to(logits.device)
    
    # Log softmax of logits for entropy calculation
    logits = torch.log_softmax(logits, dim=-1)
    
    # Shifted inputs for the entropy calculation
    tokens = input_ids[:, 1:]
    attention_mask = attention_mask[:, 1:]
    
    # Calculate entropies
    entD = torch.sum(logits * torch.exp(logits), dim=-1)[:, 1:]
    entL = torch.gather(logits[:, :-1, :], dim=-1, index=tokens[:, :, None])[:, :, 0]

    # Apply mask and replace masked values with NaN
    entD = -torch.where(attention_mask != 0, entD, torch.tensor(float('nan')).to(entD.device))
    entL = -torch.where(attention_mask != 0, entL, torch.tensor(float('nan')).to(entL.device))

    return entD, entL

def perplexity2(encoding: transformers.BatchEncoding,
               ent_values: torch.Tensor,
               median: bool = False):
    shifted_attention_mask = encoding.attention_mask[..., 1:].contiguous()
    
    ent_values = ent_values * shifted_attention_mask
    ppl = ent_values.sum(dim=1) / shifted_attention_mask.sum(dim=1)
    ppl = ppl.to("cpu").float().numpy()

    return ppl


def entropy2(p_logits: torch.Tensor,
            q_logits: torch.Tensor,
            encoding: transformers.BatchEncoding,
            pad_token_id: int,
            median: bool = False,
            sample_p: bool = False,
            temperature: float = 1.0):
    vocab_size = p_logits.shape[-1]
    total_tokens_available = q_logits.shape[-2]
    p_scores, q_scores = p_logits / temperature, q_logits / temperature

    p_proba = softmax_fn(p_scores).view(-1, vocab_size)

    if sample_p:
        p_proba = torch.multinomial(p_proba.view(-1, vocab_size), replacement=True, num_samples=1).view(-1)

    q_scores = q_scores.view(-1, vocab_size)

    ce = ce_loss_fn(input=q_scores, target=p_proba).view(-1, total_tokens_available)[:, 1:]
    # padding_mask = (encoding.input_ids != pad_token_id).type(torch.uint8)

    return ce

# Example usage with dummy data
encoding = transformers.BatchEncoding(data={'input_ids': torch.tensor([[1, 2, 3, 4], [1, 2, 3, 4]]),
                                            'attention_mask': torch.tensor([[1, 1, 1, 1], [1, 1, 1, 1]])})
p_logits = torch.randn(2, 4, 5)
q_logits = torch.randn(2, 4, 5)

p_entD, p_entL = _compute_entropy(encoding, p_logits)
q_entD, q_entL = _compute_entropy(encoding, q_logits)

    """
    Modified NT-Xent loss for image pairs with binary labels.
    
    Args:
    embeddings1 (torch.Tensor): Embeddings of the first images in the pairs.
    embeddings2 (torch.Tensor): Embeddings of the second images in the pairs.
    labels (torch.Tensor): Binary labels for the pairs (1 for similar, 0 for dissimilar).
    temperature (float): Temperature parameter for scaling.
    
    Returns:
    torch.Tensor: Computed loss.
    """
    # Normalize embeddings
    embeddings1 = F.normalize(embeddings1, dim=1)
    embeddings2 = F.normalize(embeddings2, dim=1)
    
    # Compute similarity scores
    similarity_scores = torch.sum(embeddings1 * embeddings2, dim=1) / temperature
    
    # Compute positive and negative masks
    positive_mask = labels == 1
    negative_mask = labels == 0
    
    # Compute positive and negative losses
    positive_loss = -torch.log(torch.sigmoid(similarity_scores[positive_mask])).mean()
    negative_loss = -torch.log(1 - torch.sigmoid(similarity_scores[negative_mask])).mean()
    
    # Combine losses
    loss = positive_loss + negative_loss
    
    return loss

import math
import torch
import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

from einops import rearrange, repeat

try:
    from causal_conv1d import causal_conv1d_fn
except ImportError:
    causal_conv1d_fn = None

try:
    from mamba_ssm.ops.triton.layernorm_gated import RMSNorm as RMSNormGated, LayerNorm
except ImportError:
    RMSNormGated, LayerNorm = None, None

from mamba_ssm.ops.triton.ssd_combined import mamba_chunk_scan_combined
from mamba_ssm.ops.triton.ssd_combined import mamba_split_conv1d_scan_combined


class Mamba2Simple(nn.Module):
    def __init__(
        self,
        d_model,
        d_state=64,
        d_conv=4,
        conv_init=None,
        expand=2,
        headdim=128,
        ngroups=1,
        A_init_range=(1, 16),
        dt_min=0.001,
        dt_max=0.1,
        dt_init_floor=1e-4,
        dt_limit=(0.0, float("inf")),
        learnable_init_states=False,
        activation="swish",
        bias=False,
        conv_bias=True,
        # Fused kernel and sharding options
        chunk_size=256,
        use_mem_eff_path=True,
        layer_idx=None,  # Absorb kwarg for general module
        device=None,
        dtype=None,
    ):
        factory_kwargs = {"device": device, "dtype": dtype}
        super().__init__()
        self.d_model = d_model
        self.d_state = d_state
        self.d_conv = d_conv
        self.conv_init = conv_init
        self.expand = expand
        self.d_inner = self.expand * self.d_model
        self.headdim = headdim
        self.ngroups = ngroups
        assert self.d_inner % self.headdim == 0
        self.nheads = self.d_inner // self.headdim
        self.dt_limit = dt_limit
        self.learnable_init_states = learnable_init_states
        self.activation = activation
        self.chunk_size = chunk_size
        self.use_mem_eff_path = use_mem_eff_path
        self.layer_idx = layer_idx

        # Order: [z, x, B, C, dt]
        d_in_proj = 2 * self.d_inner + 2 * self.ngroups * self.d_state + self.nheads
        self.in_proj = nn.Linear(self.d_model, d_in_proj, bias=bias, **factory_kwargs)

        conv_dim = self.d_inner + 2 * self.ngroups * self.d_state
        self.conv1d = nn.Conv1d(
            in_channels=conv_dim,
            out_channels=conv_dim,
            bias=conv_bias,
            kernel_size=d_conv,
            groups=conv_dim,
            padding=d_conv - 1,
            **factory_kwargs,
        )
        if self.conv_init is not None:
            nn.init.uniform_(self.conv1d.weight, -self.conv_init, self.conv_init)
        # self.conv1d.weight._no_weight_decay = True

        if self.learnable_init_states:
            self.init_states = nn.Parameter(torch.zeros(self.nheads, self.headdim, self.d_state, **factory_kwargs))
            self.init_states._no_weight_decay = True

        self.act = nn.SiLU()

        # Initialize log dt bias
        dt = torch.exp(
            torch.rand(self.nheads, **factory_kwargs) * (math.log(dt_max) - math.log(dt_min))
            + math.log(dt_min)
        )
        dt = torch.clamp(dt, min=dt_init_floor)
        # Inverse of softplus: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/72759
        inv_dt = dt + torch.log(-torch.expm1(-dt))
        self.dt_bias = nn.Parameter(inv_dt)
        # Just to be explicit. Without this we already don't put wd on dt_bias because of the check
        # name.endswith("bias") in param_grouping.py
        self.dt_bias._no_weight_decay = True

        # A parameter
        assert A_init_range[0] > 0 and A_init_range[1] >= A_init_range[0]
        A = torch.empty(self.nheads, dtype=torch.float32, device=device).uniform_(*A_init_range)
        A_log = torch.log(A).to(dtype=dtype)
        self.A_log = nn.Parameter(A_log)
        # self.register_buffer("A_log", torch.zeros(self.nheads, dtype=torch.float32, device=device), persistent=True)
        self.A_log._no_weight_decay = True

        # D "skip" parameter
        self.D = nn.Parameter(torch.ones(self.nheads, device=device))
        self.D._no_weight_decay = True

        # Extra normalization layer right before output projection
        assert RMSNormGated is not None
        self.norm = RMSNormGated(self.d_inner, eps=1e-5, norm_before_gate=False, **factory_kwargs)

        self.out_proj = nn.Linear(self.d_inner, self.d_model, bias=bias, **factory_kwargs)

    def forward(self, u, seq_idx=None):
        """
        u: (B, L, D)
        Returns: same shape as u
        """
        batch, seqlen, dim = u.shape

        zxbcdt = self.in_proj(u)  # (B, L, d_in_proj)
        A = -torch.exp(self.A_log)  # (nheads) or (d_inner, d_state)
        initial_states=repeat(self.init_states, "... -> b ...", b=batch) if self.learnable_init_states else None
        dt_limit_kwargs = {} if self.dt_limit == (0.0, float("inf")) else dict(dt_limit=self.dt_limit)

        if self.use_mem_eff_path:
            # Fully fused path
            out = mamba_split_conv1d_scan_combined(
                zxbcdt,
                rearrange(self.conv1d.weight, "d 1 w -> d w"),
                self.conv1d.bias,
                self.dt_bias,
                A,
                D=self.D,
                chunk_size=self.chunk_size,
                seq_idx=seq_idx,
                activation=self.activation,
                rmsnorm_weight=self.norm.weight,
                rmsnorm_eps=self.norm.eps,
                outproj_weight=self.out_proj.weight,
                outproj_bias=self.out_proj.bias,
                headdim=self.headdim,
                ngroups=self.ngroups,
                norm_before_gate=False,
                initial_states=initial_states,
                **dt_limit_kwargs,
            )
        else:
            z, xBC, dt = torch.split(
                zxbcdt, [self.d_inner, self.d_inner + 2 * self.ngroups * self.d_state, self.nheads], dim=-1
            )
            dt = F.softplus(dt + self.dt_bias)  # (B, L, nheads)
            assert self.activation in ["silu", "swish"]

            # 1D Convolution
            if causal_conv1d_fn is None or self.activation not in ["silu", "swish"]:
                xBC = self.act(
                    self.conv1d(xBC.transpose(1, 2)).transpose(1, 2)
                )  # (B, L, self.d_inner + 2 * ngroups * d_state)
            else:
                xBC = causal_conv1d_fn(
                    x=xBC.transpose(1, 2),
                    weight=rearrange(self.conv1d.weight, "d 1 w -> d w"),
                    bias=self.conv1d.bias,
                    activation=self.activation,
                ).transpose(1, 2)

            # Split into 3 main branches: X, B, C
            # These correspond to V, K, Q respectively in the SSM/attention duality
            x, B, C = torch.split(xBC, [self.d_inner, self.ngroups * self.d_state, self.ngroups * self.d_state], dim=-1)
            y = mamba_chunk_scan_combined(
                rearrange(x, "b l (h p) -> b l h p", p=self.headdim),
                dt,
                A,
                rearrange(B, "b l (g n) -> b l g n", g=self.ngroups),
                rearrange(C, "b l (g n) -> b l g n", g=self.ngroups),
                chunk_size=self.chunk_size,
                D=self.D,
                z=None,
                seq_idx=seq_idx,
                initial_states=initial_states,
                **dt_limit_kwargs,
            )
            y = rearrange(y, "b l h p -> b l (h p)")

            # Multiply "gate" branch and apply extra normalization layer
            y = self.norm(y, z)
            out = self.out_proj(y)
        return out
