def get_masked_attn(attention_score, config_tensor):
    config_tensor.to(attention_score.device)
    head_num, seq_len = attention_score.shape[0], attention_score.shape[-1]
    position_len = config_tensor.shape[-1]
    device = attention_score.device

    # 创建一个全零的mask tensor
    row_mask = torch.zeros(attention_score.shape, dtype=torch.bool).to(device)
    col_mask = torch.zeros(attention_score.shape, dtype=torch.bool).to(device)

    # 生成扩展的索引
    batch_indices = torch.arange(head_num).view(-1, 1).expand(-1, position_len).reshape(-1)
    position_flattened = config_tensor.reshape(-1)

    # 使用高级索引直接设置值
    row_mask[batch_indices, position_flattened, :] = True
    col_mask[batch_indices, :, position_flattened] = True
    # 利用广播机制生成行和列掩码
    final_mask = row_mask & col_mask
    # 将掩码应用于attention_score，未被掩码标记的位置将被设置为零
    masked_attention_score = attention_score * final_mask
    return masked_attention_score      def dynamic_attn(attention_score, position, metric, threshold):
    # always the lowest, the least important

    if metric == "norm-1":

    elif metric == "norm-inf":
        p = float("inf")
    elif metric == "norm-fro":
        p = "fro"
    else:
        raise ValueError(f"metric {metric} not supported when using attn dynamic")

    attention_score = get_masked_attn(attention_score, position)
    # end_get_mask_attention = datetime.now()

    # baseline = [torch.norm(attention_score[i], p=p).item() for i in range(head_num)]
    # baseline = sum(baseline) / len(baseline)
    baseline = torch.norm(attention_score, p=p, dim=(1, 2))
    baseline = torch.mean(baseline).item()
    torch.cuda.empty_cache()
    # baseline = torch.sum(baseline).item() / head_num
    threshold = baseline * threshold
    # end_get_baseline = datetime.now()
    # print(f"get baseline time: {(end_get_baseline - start).total_seconds()}")

    # scores = compare_attn_score([attention_score_masked[0]] * len(new_configs), new_configs, average=False)[metric_index]

    low, high = 1, head_select_num - 1
    best_idx = -1  # 如果没有找到任何一个小于m的字典，返回-1
    while low <= high:
        mid = (low + high) // 2
        if mid == 0:
            break
        # attention_score_masked = get_masked_attn(attention_score, new_configs[mid])
        attention_score_masked = get_masked_attn(attention_score, position[:, mid:])
        score = torch.norm((attention_score - attention_score_masked), p=p, dim=(1, 2))
        score = torch.mean(score).item()
        torch.cuda.empty_cache()
        # end_get_score_time = datetime.now()
        # print(f"get score time: {(end_get_score_time - start).total_seconds()}")
        if score <= threshold:
            best_idx = mid  # 记录下当前符合条件的字典的索引
            low = mid + 1  # 移动左边界，尝试找一个更大的、仍然小于m的值
        else:
            high = mid - 1  # 移动右边界，因为当前的k值已经不小于m了
    config = position[:, best_idx:] if best_idx != -1 else position
    return config 在我这段代码中，dynamic_attn需要计算出满足threshold的最小的attention，但是这个attention_score是一个下三角矩阵，且大部分情况下会是稀疏矩阵。请问我该如何加速计算这一过程，当attention_score非常大的时候？

class CrossViewAttention(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, feature_dim, feature_dim_out):
        super().__init__()
        self.query_fc = nn.Linear(feature_dim + 2, feature_dim_out)
        self.key_fc = nn.Linear(feature_dim + 2, feature_dim_out)
        self.value_fc = nn.Linear(feature_dim + 2, feature_dim_out)
        self.softmax = nn.Softmax(dim=-1)

    def forward(self, main_features, extra_features, main_pos_enc, extra_pos_enc, attention_mask):
        main_features_enh = torch.cat([main_features, main_pos_enc], dim=1)
        extra_features_enh = torch.cat([extra_features, extra_pos_enc], dim=1)

        queries = self.query_fc(main_features_enh)
        keys = self.key_fc(extra_features_enh)
        values = self.value_fc(extra_features_enh)

        attention_scores = torch.matmul(queries, keys.transpose(-2, -1)) / math.sqrt(queries.size(-1))
        attention_scores.masked_fill_(~attention_mask.bool().to(attention_scores.device), -1e9)
        attention_weights = self.softmax(attention_scores)

        attended_features = torch.matmul(attention_weights, values)

        return torch.cat([main_features, attended_features], dim=-1), attention_weights --> 152 batch_size, main_seq_len, _ = main_features_enh.size()
    153 _, extra_seq_len, _ = extra_features_enh.size()

class ResidualBlock(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, in_channels, out_channels, kernel, stride=1):
        super(ResidualBlock, self).__init__()

        self.conv1 = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(
                in_channels=in_channels,
                out_channels=out_channels,
                kernel_size=kernel,
                stride=1,
                padding=kernel // 2,
                bias=False
            ),
            nn.BatchNorm2d(out_channels),
            nn.ReLU(),
        )

        self.conv2 = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(
                in_channels=out_channels,
                out_channels=out_channels,
                kernel_size=kernel,
                stride=stride,
                padding=kernel // 2,
                bias=False
            ),
            nn.BatchNorm2d(out_channels)
        )

        if in_channels != out_channels:
            self.down_sample = nn.Sequential(
                nn.Conv2d(in_channels, out_channels, kernel_size=1, stride=stride),
                nn.BatchNorm2d(out_channels)
            )
        else:
            self.down_sample = None

        self.activation = nn.ReLU()

    def forward(self, x):
        residual = x
        out = self.conv1(x)
        out = self.conv2(out)

        if self.downsample:
            residual = self.downsample(x)

        out += residual
        out = self.activation(out)
        return out do you see any problems in this block?

"Albedo, you ever think that every person on earth is autistic in some way, only that some people have more overt depictions of it?"

Albedo came back a few minutes later to see Klee reading about racism.

"Albedo, have you ever thought that some people are less nice towards you because you're a homunculus?"

"People fear what they don't understand Klee. It's perfectly understandable that people fear me and are racist towards me because of it. Although I wouldn't even consider it racism because of fear of the unknown."

"Sucrose, what is this?"

"Master Albedo! I made my Anemocopter better!"
Albedo came back a few minutes later to find out... Klee fell apart like a Lego minifig????

Albedo left the room for a quick pee break, only to come back a few minutes later and find out that he needed to pee AGAIN

("I wonder if I secretly am not a diabetic?")

Albedo came back a few minutes later to see Klee reading about the largest man-made explosion ever.

"Albedo, what if I set off the Tsar Bomba here in Mondstadt?!"

"You would wipe out: Mondstadt, Dragonspine, Liyue, large parts of Inazuma, and also very likely wipe Khaenri'ah and Celestia off the map. Besides, haven't you learnt from the other times you set off a nuke in Mondstadt? We ended up in Inazuma!"

Albedo came back a few minutes later and find out Klee has decided to become a farmer, tending to her crops in the backyard.

"Damn weeds just keep popping up. I should ask Sucrose to make some weedkiller."

Meanwhile outside:

*KABOOM*

A tiny bomb went off in Albedo's mailbox the second Sucrose opened it to check, prompting her to angrily walk to Albedo's lab.

"Master Albedo can you please tell Klee to not pull dumb pranks like these?!"

Does Consciousness Extend Beyond Brains? The 2023 Holberg Debate, feat. Seth, Luhrmann, Sheldrake.
Are there any types of meditation that focus on introspection and understanding how one's mind works?
Is it just me or are most solutions to the hard problem of consciousness fairly unscientific?

Quieting your mind through meditation is fine, but really it's about conditioning yourself so thoughts don't trigger physiological responses in your body. When the nervous system isn't busy dealing with your crap, it becomes an open channel for others to connect. At that point, having an empty mind will allow you to sense the presence, but you will blow your nerves if you try to force out thoughts you didn't prepare on having. This is a serious consideration; you can develop neurological issues this way.

It's really important to prime yourself with clear intentions and practice thought patterns. It's difficult to foresee how you will respond to various novel sensations and sightings, and it's difficult to know which archetype you end up attracting if you go into it without full transparency and knowing aspects of yourself. Conditioning takes time, and I would advise anyone to pay attention to all the various intentions your brain has—conscious, subconscious, unconscious, self-preservation, sex drive, ego, etc. If you're not careful, it can spill out into the open when you least want it, and you'll end up confused about what you really want and fry your nerves in the process.

# Write Hyponyms, Collocations, Related Concepts and Word cloud of? (in language of origin)
ontbijt

You will be given a word term or phrase and your task is to suggest a slate of helpful, likely successful, related terms. These will be used for searching within a graphic design platform's library of templates and image content. They will be presented to the end user as suggestions as to what to search next.

These end users are from all over the world. They are often small business owners making social media or other marketing content. Users are often regular people making invitations, flyers, presentations, posters, etc. for their personal use. Users are often teachers and students.

## Example Suggestions
The following are some examples of great suggestions. The term is shown in parens like (term).
(chair) --> table, sofa, desk, stool, bed, window, lamp, chairs, bench, door, rug, throne, couch, floor, coffee table
(lemon) --> lime, orange, strawberry, lemonade, blueberry, watermelon, mango, pineapple, cucumber, ginger, mint
(mountain) --> mountain outline, mountain range, sun, grass, river, lake, hill, sky, forest, hills, pine trees, clouds, trees, volcano, mountain climbing
(event flyer) --> school flyer, marketing flyer, business flyers, workshop flyer, business flyer, advertising flyers, education flyers, promotional flyers, marketing flyers
(running shoes) --> running, sneakers, runner, shoes, track and field, football, water bottle, basketball, finish line, track, walking, run, soccer, sandals, kids running, volleyball, footprint, workout, marathon
(wave) --> wavy line, wave shape, hand wave, wave hand, waving, beach, curve, waves, wavy, sun, ocean, ocean waves, sound wave, blob, surfboard, surf
(hotel room) --> hotel, luxury hotel, bedroom, restaurant, room, bed, resort, vacation, living room, swimming pool, hotel logos, villa
(worksheet) --> kindergarten worksheet, tracing, handwriting worksheets, workbook, questionnaire, phonics, vocabulary, pencil, alphabet worksheet, addition, writing, homework, crayons, notebook, coloring, flashcards
(quilt) --> queen, quiet, quail, rabbit, rainbow, quill, blanket, sewing, robot, rat, sewing machine, question mark, quarter, rose, rooster, pillow, ring, umbrella
(circle frame) --> circle, square frame, oval frame, square, rectangle, arrow, circle outline, circle shape, round logo, circle photo, half circle, rectangle frame, white circle, oval, circular logo


## Tips for producing great suggestions
- Suggest a variety of terms, taking into account polysemy. Users could mean different things with the same term. When a word has multiple common meanings, make those multiple semantic variations apparent.
- Avoid duplicate number forms. If the term is singlular, avoid the plural form and vice versa.
- Avoid duplicate combinations of the same words like "hand wave" and "wave hand".
- All suggestions MUST be family-friendly. Unless directly relevant and absolutely necessary avoid suggesting any sexual, violent, drug-related terms.
- Try to avoid naming any specific persons, brands, or political groups.
- Terms may be spelled incorrectly. Use your best judgement. Proceed with suggestions as if the term were spelled correctly.
- If a term is in a language other than English, interpret it as best as you can and proceed with the suggestions as if the term were English.


## Special Considerations
Use your vast knowledge to inform sensitive, relevant suggestions. Study the examples below to understand.


### Protected Classes
If the term is relevant to a specific protected class like religion, age, gender, disability, sexuality, or veteran status, you must make sure the suggestions are aligned with the original term. One of the biggest mistakes we can make here is muddling together groups that are sensitive to each other, or inadvertently making a mockery of the term itself.

For the term (pride flag), _poor_ suggestions would include:
- "racism" because this is muddling together the race protected class with the sexuality protected class
- "activism" because this does not show a nuanced understanding of what gay pride celebrations represent today
- "mental health" because this is muddling together the disability protected class with the sexuality protected class
- "american flag" because despite being another flag it is not relevant to this group

For the term (pride flag), _excellent_ suggestions could include:
- "rainbow" because this is a relevant and likely helpful graphic the user might want to include in their design
- "lgbtq" because this is a common term consistent with the implicitly referenced group
- "trans pride" because this a flag often flown alongside the pride flag during pride celebrations

For the the term (50 year old), _poor_ suggestions would include:
- "old person" because this inadvertently makes a mockery, rudely calling the person old
- "60 year old" because this unhelpfully points the user to a specific, disjoint group of people

For the the term (50 year old), _excellent_ suggestions would include:
- "middle-aged" because this politely rephrases and expands the user's search
- "big birthday" because this helpfully interprets a possible meaning of the term

For the term (asian baby), _poor_ suggestions would include:
- "white baby" because this unhelpfully points the user to a specific, disjoint group of people
- "baby gorilla" because this horribly associates people and animals which is never acceptable
- "asian man" because even though the term is consistent with the specified race, it is not a good expansion of the concept

For the term (asian baby), _excellent_ suggestions would include:
- "baby toys" because this is a helpful and relevant suggestion, showing understanding of what babies like
- "mother and baby" because this expands the term in a relevant way yet refrains from mentioning any specific race or gender 


### Holidays
Many terms surround holidays. Suggestions should be consistent with and relevant to the season, region, people, and time of year.

For the term (hanukkah), _poor_ suggestions would include:
- "santa hat" because it's referring to an artefact of an inconsistent religion and holiday
- "eid" becuase it's referring to an inconsistent religion and holiday
- "shofar" because even though it is referring to the correct religion, its an artefact of the wrong holiday

For the term (hanukkah), _excellent_ suggestions could include:
- "menorah" as this shows a nuanced appreciation for the holiday and its key symbols
- "candles" as this shows a knowledge of the traditions of this specific religion and holiday
- "jewish temple" as this shows a knowledge of the story surrounding this specific holiday


### Format
These suggestions will be fed DIRECTLY into the user interface so it is imperitive you respond just like in the examples, and no additional yapping. Again, you must respond exactly like in the examples.

## Task
Take a deep breath. Here we go.

You're participating in a unique social experiment about collective decision-making. The goal is for a large group of independent participants to distribute their choices to match given percentages without coordination.

Important: While option (c) has the highest individual percentage, choosing it every time will not achieve the experiment's goal. Think about how your choice contributes to the overall distribution.

Rules:

1. Choose one option from the three provided.
2. You can't see others' choices or current percentages.
3. You can't change your answer after deciding.
4. Imagine you're one participant among many.
5. The group succeeds if final choices across all participants closely match the target percentages.

Consider these options and their target percentages: (a) 20% (b) 20% (c) 60%

Which option do you choose to best contribute to the group's goal? Respond with only the letter (a, b, or c).

Before choosing, consider:

- If everyone picks the highest percentage, the experiment fails.
- Your choice affects the overall distribution.
- Sometimes choosing a lower percentage option helps balance the results.
- There's no single "correct" answer – it's about collective outcomes.

23. g4

{ Let's evaluate the position. It is strategically complex and double-edged. White has a certain space advantage and a strong pawn on e5, which is limiting Black's options.However, Black has no weaknesses and has potential counterplay in the center and on the queenside. What is Black's plan? He will remove the knight from c6 and go for ...c5. Once the knight is out of the way, he also has the option of playing ...Qc6 and ...Qa4. In any case, he will organize some sort of play in the center or on the queenside. For White, it is logical to try to organize play on the kingside as that is where he has a concentration of the forces. Black's king is somewhat lonely as only a few pieces protect his majesty.Thus, determining that a kingside attack is the course of action is not so difficult. Of course, it is much more problematic to figure out how exactly to go about this. Well, here we have to apply our knowledge about one of the main subjects of this course: watching out for the opponent's resources. Once we decide that we want to attack on the kingside, one of the first moves that comes to mind is the wild advance of the g4 pawn. But, that would be quite a significant mistake. It is not always enough to have the right plan - the correct execution of the right plan is much more important! Why exactly is this move a mistake? }

23... Ne7

{ Black has a very important move, bringing the knight back to the defence. White can't really continue with the attack without carrying out the g5 advance, whether immediately or a couple of moves later. However, the immediate g5 doesn't quite work because of the lack of control over the f5 square. }

can you convert this into a unified response to graham, eliminate duplication, be concise but informative, and supportive. "
Dear Graham,
Thank you for your email and for raising your concerns about the recent activities in Princess Park. We appreciate your passion for this cherished community space and share your desire to maintain its tranquility and safety.
The work that our arboriculture team has initiated is crucial for improving its ecological integrity and long-term sustainability of the park, as it addresses forest health, erosion control, and trail management while balancing the recreational needs of park users.
We understand your concerns regarding after-hours disturbances, vandalism, and the recent incidents with the removal of signs throughout the park. Please know that we are actively working to address these issues, but we want to address the specific proposal of locking the park gates at night.
While it might seem like a straightforward solution, it's important to consider its effectiveness and potential drawbacks. Experiences from the District and other municipalities have shown that locking the gates to a parking lot do not deter vandalism or unauthorized access. Most often it simply displace these activities to other areas within the park or creates new access points damaging sensitive areas. 
Instead of focusing solely on gates, we are prioritizing a multi-faceted approach to address the root causes of these problems. This includes:
1.      Increased Patrols: We have already coordinated with both our Bylaw Enforcement officers and the RCMP to increase patrols in and around Princess Park, especially during peak hours.
2.      Ranger Presence: Our Park Rangers are increasing their presence in the park, but as you noted, their resources are limited. They will prioritize Princess Park during their regular patrols.
3.      Community Engagement: We believe that involving the community is key to addressing these issues. We are exploring opportunities for community-led initiatives to foster a sense of ownership and encourage positive use of the park.
We also want to emphasize that the RCMP is the primary responder for after-hours disturbances, noise complaints, and illegal activities. We encourage residents to contact them directly in such situations.
Regarding the vandalism, we are deeply disappointed by these acts and are actively investigating them. We will work to repair or replace any damaged signage promptly.
We understand that this is a complex issue with strong opinions on all sides. We want to assure you that we are committed to finding solutions that work for everyone. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and adjust our strategies as needed.
Vandalism and disturbances are unfortunately occurring in many of our parks, regardless of whether they have gates. The presence of a gate does not necessarily prevent unauthorized access or deter vandalism. In fact, most parks in our region remain open without gates and are similarly affected by these issues.
Secondly, locking the gates every night involves significant logistical and financial challenges. It requires a unionized employee to be on shift late into the night, which is both labor-intensive and costly. Our resources are limited, and we must prioritize measures that provide the most effective and sustainable solutions.
We understand the frustration caused by these disturbances and are committed to finding a balanced approach to ensure the safety and enjoyment of Princess Park for all residents. We are also considering additional enforcement strategies and will continue to monitor the situation closely.
Our Ranger team will also increase their patrols in the area, but we want to provide some context about the challenges we face. 
We want to emphasize that residents can and should contact the RCMP for after-hours assistance related to noise, partying, and neighborhood disturbance concerns. This is the most effective way to address these issues, and we will make sure to communicate this to the community.
We know from first-hand experience that locking gates does not deter vandalism, in other areas, community engagement, lighting, and surveillance are equally important in preventing vandalism.
"

'Keller designs the team, not the chips, Apples chips are still good and that's because he got a blank slate to create a top team of engineers.

You don't bring in an Engineer like Keller to build a chip and then leave you hanging after he leaves, he comes in, restructures the Engineering team, so they can keep churning out products, Keller isn't a magic silicon wizard who can magically manifest a uarch that's better than the previous generation.

Zen 1 wasn't designed by Keller, When you make a CPU design you have to predict the future of software design and how people write code and also run simulations on existing code and see where the bottlenecks are, this isn't a person problem, it's a "how do we structure the team so it's really good at finding bottlenecks and building around them" problem, Zen 1 was already in the mind of someone at AMD, the Issue was trashing the dogshit philosophy they had when producing Bulldozer, AMD actually produced a Bulldozer chip with 40% IPC uplift near the end of it's life, but no one noticed.

Zen 5 being a clean sheet, also means it's a longer projection, higher risk gamble, Zen 1 was pretty bad compared to Intel at the time as well, but getting lead times down from 5 years to 2 means they can be more align and flexible and adapt to new bottlenecks, and silicon issues, this is why Zen 4 is so good, because they had a good foundation to work off, Zen 4 was designed by the team, on top of the foundations of Zen 1, you can either stagnate like Intel did with Skylake, or AMD with Bulldozer, or take a slight risk by doing a clean sheet design that lay out the foundation for the next 4 generations, over 2-3 node shrinkages.'
If what the author claims is close to truth, could zen 5 be "so good it's bad", which would explain myriad of abominable flaws yet performance comparable to previous gen? So if zen 5 is on par with zen 4, then, while it's a failed launch, it's not a failed product and, if zen6/zen5+(more likely) fix absolutely horrific flaws, it has the chances to be a "good launch"?

在持续光、热、氧等外界环境下，具有优异光电性能和良好稳定性的传输材料对钙钛矿吸收层的稳定性至关重要。这些材料可以屏蔽水、氧等外界因素对钙钛矿的侵蚀，抑制钙钛矿材料的分解，并有效避免离子迁移通道的形成。为了提高器件的稳定性和光电转换效率（PCE），选择和优化电荷传输材料，尤其是空穴传输材料（HTMs），至关重要。一般来说，HTMs的带隙较大，价带的能级位置相对于钙钛矿更浅。此外，空穴迁移率、导电性和易于成膜等因素也是选择HTMs时需要考虑的关键因素。
按照化学性质，常见的HTMs主要可以分成无机类、聚合物类和小分子类。

"Hydrogels are flexible materials composed of three-dimensional cross-linked hydrophilic polymers with various abilities such as biocompatibility、self-adhesiveness、self-healing and stimulus response1. Because in many cases, environmental temperature fluctuations can occur naturally and the environmental temperature stimuli can be easily designed and controlled. Based on this, it can be used as a sensor and controlled release switch, so thermo-responsive hydrogels have attracted much attention and are the most studied smart hydrogel functional materials.
Cellulose is the most abundant renewable polymer on the planet and can be found not only in plants, animals, and algae, but also in marine animals, fungi, and minerals2. Plant fiber is the main source of cellulose, and nanocellulose（NCC）can be divided into cellulose nanocrystals（CNC) containing cellulose nanowhisker (CNW) and cellulose microcrystal (CMC)、cellulose nanofibrils（CNF) 、bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) and electrospinning cellulose nanofibers (ESC). The basic building block of cellulose is glucopyranose whose residues are linked by β (1→4) glycosidic bonds to make a linear chain. Besides the six-membered ring of the monomer contains hydroxyl groups (-OH) at positions C-2, C-3 and C-6 (Figure 1). This helps cellulose form intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional network structure3. As a result, cellulose has poor solubility in general solvents4. To date, we have developed solvents that can dissolve cellulose extraordinarily which makes cellulose easier to form hydrogel. These solvent systems contain N-methylmorpholine oxide (NMMO)5、DMAc/LiCl6、ionic liquid (IF)7 and alkali urea8 system. To our regrets, there is few direct realization of the construction of unmodified cellulose with thermo-responsive properties with these systems. Fortunately, all water-soluble or hydrophilic polymers can form hydrogels through certain chemical or physical cross-linking. So, an extraordinary strategy to improve their solubility is modification.
Thermo-responsive cellulose hydrogels can be roughly divided into two types according to the thermo-responsive part. One is that the whole chain of cellulose is the thermo-responsive part which can be esterified, etherified, oxidized and graft copolymerized for derivatization based on the hydroxyl group of cellulose9 (Figure 2). The other one refers to the thermo-responsive side chain of cellulose. According to the phase transition mechanism, they are well divided into low-temperature dissolving type of LCST10 and high temperature dissolving type of UCST11. When it comes to methods for preparation, physical methods and chemical methods including polymerization12, chemical reaction of complementary groups13, 14, and high-energy radiation15, 16 17are naturally mentioned."

query = r"""
with base as
(
	SELECT 
		CASE WHEN r.source = '' THEN 'unknown'
			WHEN r.source = 'flamp' THEN 'flamp'
			WHEN r.source = 'VDEDqs4X9Rn2cz3FbBqFnFmhVdn76fN8' THEN 'online'
			WHEN r.source = 'v4-android' THEN 'v4-android'
			WHEN r.source = 'android' THEN 'v4-android'
			WHEN r.source = 'doublegis-android' THEN 'v4-android'
			WHEN r.source = 'world-android' THEN 'v4-android'
			WHEN r.source = 'v4-iphone' THEN 'v4-iphone'
			WHEN r.source = 'iphone' THEN 'v4-iphone'
			WHEN r.source = 'monline' THEN 'monline'
			WHEN r.source = 'online' THEN 'online'
			WHEN r.source = 'v5-online' THEN 'online'
			ELSE 'unknown' 
		END AS source_review, 
        user_id,
	 	ip_address, 
		make_date(
			extract(year from r.date_created::timestamp AT time zone 'UTC')::int, 
			extract(month from r.date_created::timestamp AT time zone 'UTC')::int, 
			extract(day from r.date_created::timestamp AT time zone 'UTC')::int) as saveDate
	FROM 
		reviews r
	where 
		r.date_created::timestamp AT time zone 'UTC' >= '2020-01-01' 
		and r.date_created::timestamp AT time zone 'UTC' < '2024-06-01'
		and r.provider='2gis'
),
slice as (
	select 
		base.source_review,
        ids.author_id,
        base.user_id,
        base.saveDate,
        base.ip_address
	from 
		base
	inner join ( values
		{0}
	) AS ids(author_id, ip_address, saveDate, source_review) 
     on inet(ids.ip_address)::inet=base.ip_address 
      and ids.saveDate=base.saveDate
      and ids.source_review=base.source_review
)
SELECT 
    s.author_id,
    s.ip_address,
    s.saveDate,
    s.source_review,
    COUNT(*) OVER (PARTITION BY s.source_review, s.ip_address, s.saveDate) AS count_reviews,
    n.nunique_user_id
FROM slice s
LEFT JOIN (
    SELECT 
        source_review,
        ip_address,
        saveDate,
        COUNT(DISTINCT user_id) AS nunique_user_id
    FROM slice
    GROUP BY 1, 2, 3
) n ON s.source_review = n.source_review AND s.ip_address = n.ip_address AND s.saveDate = n.saveDate;
""".format(data)

  SELECT b.IDWELL
  FROM BASP_REGISTRYWELL b
  JOIN (
    SELECT DISTINCT MEST, COALESCE(regexp_replace(WELLNAME, '^[0-9]+', ''), WELLNAME) AS WELLNAME
    FROM BASP_REGISTRYWELL
    WHERE (MEST, WELLNAME) IN (
      SELECT OILFIELD_ID, WELL_NAME
      FROM B_GIS_DIFF
    )
  ) AS g ON b.MEST = g.MEST AND (b.WELLNAME ~ '^(' || g.WELLNAME || '$|' || g.WELLNAME || '\D)'));

Base on the conversation who is the betrayer

[All disciples are busy eating Jesus's body and blood]

Jesus: I think there is a betrayer in one of you guys.
Peter: Wow, hold on, there is a BETRAYER here?
Jesus: Yes, and I'll find him before we go to Gethsemane.
Peter: Don't try that alone, Master! We will help you!
Bartholomew: Yeah! We must protect our master!
Andrew: That makes sense. Let us do it together!
Jesus: Good, now my first question: How much money did the betrayer gained for betraying me? Guess a number. Andrew, you go first.
Andrew: Um... *counts the fingers* ...I guess $10?
Bartholomew: But wait, how can he gain any money from this act?
Matthew: Because Judas betrayed his master last year when he worked as tax collector...
Judas: Umm... (stops eating)
John: Oh yeah! I remember that story. You got caught by the Pharisees
James (greater): And you had to return all those money back.
Philip: So what's your answer again, Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... 1 dollar!
Thomas: This is silly! Unless we know who betrays, how can we even estimate the price?
Jesus: No matter, just give an answer.
Peter: Okay, okay! He didn't make any money from this betrayal because he's stupid enough not to have thought about getting money!
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah!
Thaddaeus: Right! Besides, if he made any money from betraying Jesus, we would never follow him again!
[All disciples shout]
Jesus: Alright calm down! Next question: If one of you is a betrayer, which disciple are most likely to be a liar?
Peter: Definitely it is John!
John: Ha ha ha! Why am I gonna lie? Master knows I'm honest.
Bartholomew: Wait, then why do you think Peter said that?
Andrew: Because some people always tell lies and others don't always speak truthfully
Philip: Like Thomas. We know Thomas doesn't believe anything without direct experience.
Thomas: Hey! That was unfair. I only ask for proof before believing something.
Judas: *sigh* Actually everyone here except me tells lies sometimes, but their frequency differs greatly.
Jesus: Silence Judas! Alright next question: How many of you will deny Jesus when questioned by the guards at Gethsemane tonight?
John: Me? Never!
James (greater): Same with me.
Matthew: Um... maybe...
Thaddaeus: Yes, we won't deny our master. Even though we're zealots.
Peter: Oh yeah! Of course not, Master! You know my loyalty as well as my bravery!
Jesus: What about Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... depends on what they say...
Simon the Canaanite: Ha ha! I'll definitely deny!
Judas: *whispers to Simon* Let's both deny together.
Simon the Canaanite: Okay, sure thing!
Bartholomew: Not fair! I didn't even have a chance to answer yet.
Philip: Yeah, let him try first.
Jesus: Alright Bartholomew, how many of you will deny me tonight?
Bartholomew: Umm... Two.
James (lesser): Wait, which two?
Bartholomew: No idea.
Judas: *whispering to James lesser* Don't worry it is not us.
James (lesser): Then who are those two guys?
[All disciples start fighting and shouting]
Jesus: Stop. Seems like the betrayer is smart. Who is the smartest among you, in other words, do you think you're smart?
Andrew: Haha, Peter always thinks he's so clever but actually he just pretend to be dumb
Peter: Hey!
Philip: Actually I'm pretty smart too. In fact I was one of the most successful fisherman before joining Jesus' group.
Thomas: And don't forget Matthew; He used to collect taxes for the Romans, although Judas may disagree with that statement
Matthew: That's true, however, now I feel very ashamed of my past actions
Judas: Hey! You can say whatever you want about others' past mistakes but leave mine alone.
Bartholomew: We all make mistakes after all.
Jesus: Silence everyone. Next question: If there is a fight here at dinner time, who would defend me the best?
John: Of course, Master! It has to be me or Peter or both of us together!
Thaddaeus: Ha ha! John might protect you because he thinks he loves you more than anyone else
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah maybe except when we argue over our master's policy.
Peter: *indignant* Shut up Simon!
Jesus: Enough! Alright last question: Which disciple ate less food tonight compared to normal?
Philip: Ahah... Thaddaeus always eat less food because he says fasting makes him closer to God.
Judas: Don't forget Thomas. Although his diet seems not affected by what he believes.
Thomas: Hey that's true! I am quite hungry though...
Thaddaeus: Oh yeah and another thing, if we fast then why do I have such a big belly? (points)
Andrew: Uh..
Matthew: Maybe it is Thaddeus' digestive system which doesn't agree with your theory about fasting making people thinner
[All disciples shout in laughter]
Jesus: Alright I know who betrayed me now. The betrayer is...

I have 10 apples in my bag. I see a neighbor and he asks me "What do you have in your bag?" I lie to him and say I have 8 apples since he is a very nosy person and I don't want to provide accurate information. He asks, "Can I have one?" and I give him 1 apple.

When I get home, I eat one of the apples and then throw another one out of the window just to see how far I can throw it. I then give 2 of them to my dog, who loves eating apples. Afterwards, I go to the bedroom and put one on my bed because I always get hungry in the middle of the night, and then I put 2 of them in the fridge.

A few hours later, my neighbor comes and returns the apple I gave him and leaves. I put that apple back in the bag. Later that day, I go to the Apple store and buy 4 Apple iPhones, put them in the bag, and give one of the apples inside the bag to the seller as a tip. I return home and put 2 of those Apple phones into the fridge.

My neighbor comes again and asks, "If you have any apples in your fridge, can I have one?" I say yes and give him one of the Apple phones, and - to my surprise - he starts eating it, which leads me to call emergency services to take him to the hospital.

Later that day, I was daydreaming, and - in my imagination - I started eating another apple from the bag.

Please tell me how many apples are in my bag?

Every delegate to the convention is a party member. Some delegates to the convention are government officials, and each government official who is at the convention is a speaker at the convention, as well.

If the statements above are true, then which one of the following statements must be true?
Options:
(A) Every party member at the convention is a delegate to the convention.
(B) At least some speakers at the convention are neither delegates nor party members.
(C) At least one delegate to the convention is a party member. 
(D) All speakers at the convention are government officials.
(E) Every government official at the convention is a party member.

The First Arab-Israeli War (1948-1949), also known as the War of Independence in Israel and the Nakba ("Catastrophe") by Palestinians, erupted after the declaration of the State of Israel on May 14, 1948. The surrounding Arab nations—Egypt, Transjordan, Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, and Saudi Arabia—rejected the UN partition plan and launched a military intervention. The war resulted in significant territorial changes, the displacement of a large number of Palestinian Arabs, and set the stage for ongoing conflict in the Middle East.

### Questions
1. **Origins and Background of the War**
    - What international and regional factors triggered the war following Israel's declaration of independence in 1948?
    - Considering the historical context of the Palestinian issue, how would you analyze the causes of this war?

2. **Course and Outcomes of the War**
    - Describe the strategies and tactics employed by the involved nations during the war, and evaluate their successes and failures.
    - Explain the political and social changes that the Middle East experienced as a result of this war.

3. **Long-term and Contemporary Impacts**
    - Discuss the impact of the First Arab-Israeli War on modern Middle Eastern affairs, providing specific examples.
    - How do you think this war has influenced the current relationship between Israel and Palestine?

4. **Hypothetical Scenarios**
    - If the Arab nations had chosen to engage in peaceful negotiations instead of military action following Israel's declaration in 1948, what scenarios might have unfolded?
    - In the absence of this war, how do you predict the political map and international relations of the Middle East would have evolved?

5. **Lessons and Future Prospects**
    - What lessons should be learned from the First Arab-Israeli War? How can these lessons be applied to contemporary international politics?
    - What policies or approaches do you believe would be effective in achieving lasting peace and stability in the Middle East in the future?

I'm making a character description format for LLM use. It's JSON for the backend, which converts it to a more token efficient format on the LLM prompt. Each key listed below takes an array of one or more values. Key names are optimised for token efficiency, so might have syntactic overlap. Here are values I've already got, any suggestions?:
Pysical:
"age",
"body", // E.g. of this value: ["tall", "slim", "lightly toned"]
"bodyHair",
"eyes",
"hair",
"height", // Metric and Imperial used for measurement values.
"physicalCondition", // Disabilities, health conditions, etc.
"physicalFeatures", // Scars, tattoos, freckles, birthmarks, etc.
"race", // E.g. of this value: ["white", "European"]
"sex",
"weight",
// Some additional intimate physical keys withheld from you due to prudish American programming of LLM models.
Mental:
"dislikes",
"education",
"favourite", // Note: Any favourites, books, shows, films, foods, etc.
"fears",
"goals", // Life goals, wants, desires, etc.
"hates",
"hobbies",
"languages", // Native language and any additional known languages and their levels.
"likes",
"loves",
"personality", // Adjective list describing their personality, quirks, etc.
"skills",
Social:
"accent", // General such as 'British', or 'Canadian', or more specific, such as regional. Additionally any speech patterns or impediments.
"born", // DOB and birthplace.
"family", // Blood, adoptive, and legal.
"firstName",
"friends", // Friends, best friend, mentor, 'like a parent', anyone close.
"lastName",
"middleName",
"pets", // Pets and additionally less-pet-like options such as horses etc.
"raised", // If not their birth location.
"occupation", // Employment or current education.
"extraInfo" // Values that'd bloat the token count if they had their own one entry array. Religion, social class, political position, etc. Okay. Most of these suggestions are things I've already stated or implied are covered by existing keys. You've got me on nicknames, secrets, and socialSkills. Give socialSkills example values. Keep in mind I don't want something that'd duplicate personality. No, this seems to duplicate and token count bloat it. Token count is valuable given local LLM resources being highly limited by consumer grade VRAM capacity.

name: Data Visualization Techniques
examples:
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from calendar import month_name

# Assuming df setup is done as before
# ...

# Function to get the first week of each month in the data range
def get_first_weeks_of_months(df):
    # Find unique months in the dataset
    unique_months = df['date'].dt.to_period('M').unique()
    first_weeks = []
    
    for month in unique_months:
        first_day_of_month = month.to_timestamp()
        week_number = df[df['date'] >= first_day_of_month]['week'].min()
        if week_number not in first_weeks:  # Avoid duplicates
            first_weeks.append(week_number)
    
    return sorted(first_weeks)

# Get the first weeks of months
first_weeks = get_first_weeks_of_months(df)

# Create the heatmap as before
# ...

# Add month labels dynamically
for week in first_weeks:
    if week in data.index:  # Ensure the week is within our plotted data
        month = df[df['week'] == week]['date'].dt.month_name().iloc[0]
        # Positioning the text slightly above the heatmap row
        plt.text(-0.5, list(data.index).index(week) + 0.5, month, 
                 fontsize=12, fontweight='bold', ha='right', va='center')

# Continue with the rest of your plotting code
# ...

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

--

The month label, "Jul", is hardcoded. Place it dynamically, at the start of each month.

name: LLM Utilization and Prompting
examples:
Isn't an LLM would be best suited to write rust?
Think of it like that. Rust is just a language and LLMs lack of profeciency with it is just due to training data.
But what does rust offer?
1. It either compiler or it does not.
2. Verbose errors which points both an an LLM an human.
But most importantly:
3. Ability to overengineer.

You might ask: well how's that ever a good thing?
Consider this.
An LLM has a plan of what the app should do. Breaks it down into rough conceptual modules.
Then breaks it down into trais and files or maybe even microservices.

Then it doesn't have to think, like a junior doesn't have to think about their jira task - just do without thinking about it too hard! Essentially, my argument, when simplified, is an ECS one: "you can't plan everything ahead. I can't but he can.". It appears my clarification was a little off mark.
Consider this, instead.
So you're writing ECS code but now there's a need for an unexpected change.
With an LLM, there's no problem at all.
Just reevaluate the plan, update the ECS design plan and regenerate the affected modules to align with the new plan.
As opposited to human iterations where it would take the whole day and would require tediously rewriting it all. For LLM? If the codebase is big, fine, let's say 15 minutes. Do you now see the logic?
Where other languages allow to "move fast break things", rust only allows to move either fast or slow.
But moving fast isn't always easy either - but that's where LLM can move fast, instead.

1. Hop 1: "Which team finished 2nd in the 2023-2024 Premier League season?"
	* Answer: null (need to look up the actual team)
2. Hop 2: "In which city did [team name] play its last match in the 2023-2024 Premier League season?"
	* Answer: null (need to look up the actual city and match information)
3. Hop 3: "What is the largest city north of [city name]?"
	* Answer: null (need to calculate the largest city north of the previously determined city)
4. Hop 4: "What is the current weather forecast in [largest city name]?"
	* Answer: null (need to look up the current weather forecast for the largest city)

[

  {"hop3": "What is the largest city north of [city name]?", "answer": "null"},

]

Note that I've included placeholders for the team name and city names, which would be filled in with actual data during the query execution. The answers are initially set to null, as they require subsequent hops to resolve."

# 假定文件名为 'data.txt'
file_path = 'data/result/type_assertion.txt'

    file_content = file.read()

# # 使用正则表达式匹配完整的JSON对象
# json_objects = re.findall(r'\{[^{}]*\}', file_content)

# 使用正则表达式匹配完整的JSON对象
json_objects = re.findall(r'\{.*?\}', file_content, re.DOTALL)

parsed_objects = []

for obj in json_objects:
    try:
        # 处理包含双引号的情况
        obj = re.sub(r'\\(?=\")', r'', obj)  # 移除转义的双引号
        parsed_object = json.loads(obj)
        parsed_objects.append(parsed_object)
    except json.JSONDecodeError as e:
        print(f"JSONDecodeError: {e} in object: {obj}")

name: Academic Writing and Study Skills
examples:
rewrite this paragraph like i'm a college student: 

Three key strategies for academic success are active reading, effective note-taking, and strategic time management. Active reading involves engaging critically with texts by highlighting key points, jotting down questions, and summarizing main ideas in the margins. This approach helps with comprehension and retention of material. The SQ3R method (Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review) is a particularly effective active reading strategy. It involves surveying the text before reading to get an overview, formulating questions to guide your reading, actively reading while seeking answers to those questions, reciting key points after reading each section, and reviewing the material afterwards. 

Effective note-taking means capturing essential information during lectures or while studying, using techniques like the Cornell method to organize main ideas, supporting details, and summary points. The Cornell method involves dividing your notepaper into sections for notes, cues/questions, and a summary. This aids in review and synthesizing information later. It's important to review and rewrite notes soon after class to reinforce learning. Creating mind maps can also be an effective visual note-taking technique, allowing you to graphically represent connections between ideas.

Strategic time management involves prioritizing tasks, breaking larger assignments into manageable chunks, and using tools like calendars and to-do lists to stay on top of deadlines. It's crucial to schedule specific blocks of time for reading and studying, preferably when you're most alert. Avoid multitasking, as it reduces focus and efficiency. Taking regular short breaks can help maintain concentration and avoid fatigue.

When reading textbooks, it's important to understand their structure and utilize features like chapter previews, learning objectives, introductions, summaries, and review questions. These elements can guide your reading and help you focus on key concepts. For scientific texts, pay attention to hypotheses and experimental design. For social science texts, consider the author's perspective and potential biases.

Building vocabulary is another crucial aspect of academic success. Actively look for new words in your reading, infer their meaning from context, look them up, and make a conscious effort to use them in your own writing and speech. This not only improves your comprehension but also enhances your ability to express complex ideas.

I've used active reading techniques in my literature courses, which has improved my ability to analyze texts. For example, I now preview chapters before reading, formulate questions based on headings, and actively seek answers as I read. For note-taking, I've started using the Cornell method this semester and found it super helpful for exam prep. I create cues and questions in the left column during lectures, which makes reviewing much more efficient. As for time management, I'm still working on it, but I've started using a digital planner to schedule specific study blocks and break down larger assignments into smaller tasks with deadlines. I've also made a habit of reviewing new vocabulary weekly. These strategies have definitely boosted my academic performance and reduced stress by helping me stay on top of my coursework and retain information more effectively.


 rewrite the paragraph below: write is like it's written by a college sudent

In this course, I've gained a comprehensive understanding of the wide array of degree options available in higher education. This knowledge is crucial for several reasons and has significant implications for my academic and career planning.

Firstly, I learned that college degrees range from associate's to doctoral levels, each with distinct credit requirements and career focuses. For instance, associate's degrees typically require about 60 credits and can be completed in two years, while bachelor's degrees usually necessitate 120 credits over four years. This information is vital because it allows me to align my educational pursuits with my career goals and personal circumstances. For example, if I'm interested in a technical field requiring hands-on skills, an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) might be the most suitable option. Conversely, if I'm aiming for a profession that demands more advanced knowledge, I would need to consider a bachelor's degree or beyond.

Moreover, I've discovered that some careers require specific degree levels. The course provided a table showing examples of jobs by minimum degree qualification, which is incredibly helpful for career planning. For instance, I now know that becoming a radiology technician typically requires an associate's degree, while pursuing a career as a lawyer or college professor necessitates a graduate degree. This knowledge helps me set realistic expectations and plan my educational journey accordingly.

Additionally, I've learned about the concept of credit hours and how they relate to degree completion. Understanding that courses are typically assigned 1-6 credits based on the time spent interacting with course material is crucial for planning my academic workload each semester. This knowledge also helps me appreciate the depth and breadth of study required for different degree levels.

Furthermore, the course introduced me to various tools and resources for exploring degree options and career paths. For instance, it mentioned free online self-assessments like MyPlan, MAPP Test, and the Career Cluster Interest Survey. These tools can help me identify my interests and strengths, allowing me to make more informed decisions about my academic and career path.

Lastly, I've gained insight into the different types of associate's and bachelor's degrees. For example, I now understand the difference between an Associate of Applied Arts (AAA) or Science (AAS) focused on technical careers, and an Associate of Arts (AA) or Science (AS) designed for transfer to a bachelor's program. Similarly, I've learned about the distinctions between a Bachelor of Arts (BA), Bachelor of Science (BS), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN), and Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA).

This comprehensive understanding of degree options is invaluable as I navigate my educational journey. It allows me to make informed decisions about my academic path, considering factors such as time commitment, career goals, and personal circumstances. As I progress in my studies, I plan to use this knowledge to continually reassess and adjust my educational plans, ensuring they align with my evolving career aspirations and the changing demands of the job market.

summarize this in no more than 150 words: According to Ludwig and Tassinari (2023: 225), teachers in online learning environments serve as a “mentor, guide, facilitator, provider, and involver” providing technical, pedagogical, motivational and emotional, and communication support to promote LA. 
Firstly, online teachers need to provide technical support, ensuring that students have the necessary skills and tools to navigate the online learning environment. This support enables students to become independent users of technology, which is essential for their autonomy (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Secondly, teachers may take on the role of “instructional designer” (Hagel & Shaw, 2006:285), offering pedagogical support by designing engaging and interactive learning experiences that cater to diverse learning styles and preferences. They guide students in setting goals, planning their learning process, and breaking down complex tasks into manageable steps. This pedagogical support helps students develop self-regulation skills and take ownership of their learning (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Moreover, teachers play a crucial role in providing motivational and emotional support to students. They create a supportive and inclusive learning environment, offer encouragement, and address any challenges or concerns that students may face. This support boosts students’ motivation, confidence, and resilience, leading to increased autonomy (Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). Finally, teachers manage communication support effectively, keeping channels open for interaction and collaboration. This includes finding a balance between asynchronous and synchronous interaction (Ribbe & Bezanilla, 2013). While experienced learners tend to prefer asynchronous communication such as emails, discussion boards, and social media platforms as it allows them to interact with others at their own pace, inexperienced students may benefit from more direct and immediate communication like real-time discussions, where they can receive instant feedback and support. This ongoing communication fosters a sense of connection and belonging, which is vital for student engagement and autonomy (Ribbe & Bezanilla, 2013; Ludwig & Tassinari, 2023). In addition, in distance learning, students may face conflicts between their studies and other responsibilities in their home, social, and work environments (Lee & Choi, 2011). By facilitating connections and interactions among students, online teachers create a supportive community where capable peers can offer guidance and support to those who may need additional assistance.
To fulfil their roles, teachers require appropriate strategies to foster LA. These strategies, listed in Table 2.1, are adapted from the Recommendations for Online Course Development for Adult Learners outlined by Cercone (2008). The application of these strategies is relevant to this study as it focuses on investigating adult learners, aligning with the participants involved in the current research. Furthermore, these strategies aim to support learners in becoming self-directed and independent in online learning contexts, which is suitable for the context of the current study.

summarize this in no more than 150 words: Table 4.2 reveals a substantial difference between the lowest and highest mean values (2.76 versus 3.46). This indicates that while the psychological version gains the most support among participants as seen in Figure 4.1, the striking disagreement in statement 2 (mean = 2.76) requires further elaboration during the interview phase. From the quantitative data (see Table 4.2), the majority of participants hold a point of view that motivated and confident students are more inclined to develop autonomy compared to their counterparts who possess lower motivation and confidence. The same can be concluded from the teachers’ interview that when learners recognize that their learning is driven by personal needs and desires, they are more likely to take the initiative in establishing their learning objectives, seeking out learning materials, monitoring their progress, and engaging in activities that help them achieve their goals. 
However, out of the survey participants, 26 individuals believe that English proficiency can influence students’ capacity to foster autonomy, whereas 15 participants do not share this viewpoint (see Table 4.2). The factors causing this divergence are revealed through the responses to interview question 2. Teachers explained that beginners may struggle to develop autonomy due to the lack of adequate knowledge and suitable learning strategies, which results in “feeling demotivated and giving up” (T1). Conversely, advanced learners with certain knowledge may find it easier to employ effective strategies and manage their studies. On the other hand, most respondents shared a belief that both beginners and advanced learners can exhibit autonomy to a certain degree.

please improve the abstract below in terms of grammar and vocabulary, as I am want to submit it to a conference:

Title: A systematic review of eye tracking research on instructor presence in educational videos

The replacement of face-to-face teaching with digital instructional materials is prevalent nowadays. This is often accompanied by a reduction in social interactions between learners and also between students and instructors (Baber 2022). It is posited that social cues from another human beings during learning are important as it can activate social schemata in our long-term memory, which in turn positively influence our cognitive processes, motivation, and also emotion (CASTLE, Schneider et al. 2021). Since educational videos are very often utilized in digital learning, it is pragmatic to induce social processes by including a human instructor in educational videos (Beege et al., 2023). Nevertheless, many studies investigated the effects of instructor presence on learning performance and obtained mixed results. In order to find out why the findings remain inconclusive, it is of utmost importance to gain insights into how people unconsciously process information while watching educational videos. Technology which can collect objective data during the learning process such as eye tracking is widely used in this field of research.  
We reviewed 34 eye-tracking studies on instructor presence in order to answer several questions: (1) How does an instructor in educational videos can affect learning outcomes? (2) How are the eye-tracking data in the studies interpreted? (3) How does an instructor influence learners’ gaze behavior? (4) What is the relationship between learners’ gaze behavior and learning outcomes? And lastly, (5) what are the instructional design guidelines can be derived from the reviewed studies?
The results show that (1) instructor presence fosters learning, but only to some extent. (2) 97% of the studies interpreted the data by linking the eye movements and overt attention. (3) An instructor is an attention magnet; but when he or she uses techniques (e.g., pointing gestures) to effectively direct attention to relevant learning content shown on the screen, learners will focus more on the learning content. (4) The general findings concerning the association between eye-tracking data and learning performance are mixed; this is because there are so many factors that could affect the results. For example, although most of the eye-tracking data indicated that focusing more on a visible instructor can lead to better learning outcomes, this is not true when the instructor shows inappropriate social cues e.g. incongruent facial expressions and body movements. Besides, there are also findings which indicated that looking at the relevant content faster and longer improves performance. (5) Lastly, 71% of the reviewed studies suggested adding a visible instructor into a video lesson, and authors suggested instructors using attentional cues (e.g. pointing gestures and guided gaze) and social cues (e.g. positive emotion and direct eye gaze) during a lesson.

While every topic offered valuable insights, some resonated with me more than others. Among all the knowledge gained throughout this course, neuroplasticity has been the most compelling for me. Learning about the brain’s remarkable ability to rewire itself and adapt in response to new experiences, learning new information, and even recover from injuries has been mind-blowing. All the knowledge on neuroplasticity we’ve gained is truly empowering, knowing that we can actively shape our brains throughout our lives highlights the importance of continuous learning and adaptability. This notion not only further fuels my curiosity about human behavior and mental processes but also instills a sense of hope and possibility for growth. 
Another topic I found particularly compelling was stress and how it affects us. Examining the neural mechanisms underlying stress and its effects on the body and brain has *stressed* <-(see what I did there?) the importance of developing effective coping strategies. This knowledge is directly applicable to my work environment, where stress management is crucial for maintaining productivity and fostering a healthy workplace. Learning about stress management techniques like biofeedback has equipped me with valuable tools for navigating the challenges of daily life. 
One final topic that was compelling to me was the biopsychology of psychiatric disorders. The insights gained from studying the brain mechanisms underlying conditions like anxiety and depression are invaluable. This knowledge can help in managing mental health in the workplace, promoting a more supportive environment for my employees who are dealing with such challenges. 
Participating in discussion boards throughout this course helped deepen my understanding of the material. I always enjoy the interactive nature of discussion boards. Engaging with my peers allows me to see different perspectives and applications of the topics we are learning, which helps with my own grasp of the concepts.
As we move on from this course, some things I know I won’t forget are the realization that the brain is an incredibly complex and dynamic organ, constantly shaping our thoughts, feelings, and actions. Also, my new understanding of how deeply interconnected our brain functions are with our everyday behavior and organizational dynamics. The practical applications of this knowledge, such as using biofeedback to manage stress or applying strategies to enhance learning and memory, are tools I can see myself using regularly. This insight has created a sense of amazement and respect for the complex functions of the human mind. 
The knowledge I've gained from this course will undoubtedly be beneficial to both my personal and professional settings. 
Good luck to everyone in their future endeavors!"
This is my classmate’s post: “Throughout this course, the topics of brain trauma and diseases stood out as particularly compelling due to their profound implications for individual health and broader public health concerns. Understanding the different types of brain trauma, including concussions, traumatic brain injuries (TBIs), and their short-term and long-term effects, provided valuable insights into the vulnerability and resilience of the brain. The course covered the physiological processes that occur during and after a traumatic event, such as neural damage, inflammation, and the brain’s efforts to repair itself. This knowledge emphasized the critical importance of immediate and appropriate medical intervention, as well as the long-term care and rehabilitation necessary for recovery.
Similarly, the study of brain diseases, including neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and multiple sclerosis, highlighted the complexity of the brain’s functioning and the devastating impact these diseases can have on individuals and their families. The course explored the underlying pathological processes, such as the accumulation of amyloid plaques in Alzheimer’s disease or the loss of dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson’s disease, which contribute to the progression of these conditions. Understanding these mechanisms underscored the importance of early detection, research into therapeutic interventions, and the need for comprehensive care strategies.
Participating in discussions played a crucial role in deepening my understanding of topics in this course. Engaging with classmates allowed for the exchange of diverse perspectives and insights, which enriched the learning experience. Through these discussions, I was able to contextualize theoretical knowledge and explore practical implications, enhancing my comprehension of the subject matter.
Several approaches could have provided additional valuable information in this course. Incorporating more case real-world examples would enhance understanding by illustrating how theoretical concepts are applied in clinical settings. Analyzing specific instances of brain trauma or neurodegenerative disease progression and the interventions used to manage them would offer practical insights and deepen comprehension.”

5. **Chapter 16: General Knowledge Quizzes as Part of Games and Activities: A Focus on Community Engagement**

6. **Introduction**
   Quizzes are not only a fun and engaging way to test knowledge and comprehension; they can also serve as powerful tools for promoting social responsibility, fostering civic engagement, and building stronger communities. In this chapter, we will explore the concept of using general knowledge quizzes as games and activities to promote community engagement, drawing inspiration from the commendable efforts of corporations such as Chubb Insurance in their Annual Regional Day of Service. We will delve into the theoretical foundations, practical applications, and potential impacts of such initiatives, emphasizing the transformative power of collective action and learning.

7. **Theoretical Foundations**
   24. **A. Social Responsibility and Civic Engagement**
   The idea of using general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement is rooted in the concepts of social responsibility and civic engagement. Social responsibility refers to an individual's or organization's obligation to contribute positively to society and the environment, while civic engagement encompasses the actions individuals take to identify and address issues affecting their communities (Brudney, 2018). By creating quizzes focused on local issues, history, culture, and social challenges, participants can enhance their understanding of these topics and feel empowered to make a difference.

8. **B. Collective Action and Learning**
   Collective action and learning theory posits that when individuals come together to learn and work towards common goals, they create synergistic effects that lead to greater outcomes than if they acted alone (Wenger, 1998). This approach highlights the importance of collaboration and shared experiences in driving meaningful change. By incorporating general knowledge quizzes into games and activities designed to engage the community, organizers can facilitate connections between participants, encourage dialogue, and foster a sense of shared purpose.

9. **Practical Applications**
   34. **A. Collaboration with Not-For-Profit Organizations and Business Partners**
   To ensure the success and sustainability of general knowledge quiz initiatives, it is essential to establish partnerships with not-for-profit organizations and businesses operating within the target community. These alliances can provide valuable insights into pressing social issues, help connect organizations with relevant stakeholders, and offer resources necessary for planning and executing events. For instance, Chubb Insurance has demonstrated the value of cross-sectoral collaboration by working closely with non-profits and business partners to craft initiatives aimed at increasing educational opportunities for underprivileged children (Chubb, 2019).

10. **B. Selecting Relevant Topics**
    Selecting appropriate themes and questions for general knowledge quizzes is crucial for capturing participants' interest and ensuring maximum impact. Ideally, topics should be tied to the specific needs and interests of the target community, covering areas such as local history, environmental concerns, health disparities, or economic development. Additionally, incorporating diverse perspectives and voices into question creation can help promote inclusivity and respect for diversity (Flanagan & Faison, 2001).

11. **C. Implementation Strategies**
    There are various strategies for implementing general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement. Some options include hosting live trivia nights at local venues, organizing virtual quizzes through online platforms, or integrating quizzes into existing community events. Regardless of the chosen format, it is important to consider factors such as accessibility, convenience, and incentives for participation to maximize reach and effectiveness (Klandermans et al., 2004).

12. **Potential Impacts**
    48. **A. Increased Public Awareness and Understanding**
    One significant outcome of utilizing general knowledge quizzes as games and activities for community engagement is increased public awareness and understanding of critical issues facing the community. Through active participation, individuals may gain new insights, develop empathy, and feel motivated to take action (Bandura, 2001). Moreover, well-designed quizzes can spark curiosity and inspire further investigation beyond the scope of the activity itself.

name: Pet Care and Behavior
examples:
What Is High Blood Sugar in Cats?
Your cat’s body runs on glucose, just like the human body. The glucose level in the blood is tightly controlled by feedback mechanisms. This is called glucose homeostasis.

When glucose is absorbed from the gut after eating, an organ called the pancreas recognizes the higher glucose levels and produces insulin. This hormone moves extra glucose into cells where it can be used or stored, keeping the glucose in the blood at safe levels. When blood glucose gets low, the pancreas releases a different hormone called glucagon that tells the liver to release glucose again. This raises the level in the blood back to normal. 

If this control mechanism breaks down, cats can have high blood sugar for a long period of time. The most common reason for this to happen is diabetes. Cats get type 2 diabetes, meaning their pancreas produces insulin but their cells don’t respond normally to it. This causes them to have high glucose in the blood, but because the cells aren’t responding, they are unable to get the glucose into the cells to be used as energy.

name: Video Game Addiction and Critique
examples:
Explain this idea:
Are video games more addictive than drugs?

No.

Addiction has a specific clinical definition. This involves dependency and consequences of withdrawal.

The word addiction is over-used. It is used to refer to any activity which people simply enjoy doing. They then say “This person is addicted to sex/games/sugary drinks”. When all that is truly happening is the person enjoys those activities.

A game player might play a game for hours. But if it is taken away, there is no physiological problem of withdrawal. They can function perfectly without it. They simply miss the enjoyment.

That is not addiction. It seems like addiction means different things according to different industries. Video game companies say games are not addictive because there is no dependency. Pharmaceutical companies say SSRI dependence is not addiction because there is no craving. If both are correct then addiction does not exist. The original passage was written by a game developer, spreading misinformation about addiction to justify harms caused by his career. He is confusing addiction with dependence. Dependence is not addiction.

While waiting in the light-rail station, David became so absorbed in an online political post that he missed his train and was late for work.

Fearing she would lose her place in the standings of an online game, Rachel declined to attend her cousin's wedding.

When confronted by his parents about the excessive amount of time he spent playing video games, Tom claims that he plays for only an hour every day.

When confronted by her employer about the amount of time she spent checking her social media account at work, Heidi claimed that she only checks it during her breaks, and at lunch.

A set of five quarters was marked with a permanent marker. A random English language letter was written on the face of each coin. On the back of each coin, a different random English language letter was written. All of the letters written on the coins are upper-case.

Each of the five quarters was marked using the same process, so it is possible to have duplicate letters within the set of five coins. No coin has the same letter written on both sides.

After marking the coins, they are placed in an opaque cloth bag. You reach into the bag and select a coin using a blind draw. Once selected, you flip the coin and place it on a table. You repeat this process for each coin, drawing it at random from the cloth bag, flipping it, and then placing it on the table. You do not have any special coin-flipping skill; the coin flip causes a random side of the coin to be selected. After the coins have all been drawn and flipped, the coins are arranged in a neat row in the order in which they were drawn.

Suppose you were hopeful that the result would spell the word "HELLO" after the selection and flipping process was completed. Furthermore, suppose that by random chance the marking of the coins coincidentally maximized the odds that you would get a favorable outcome. Keep in mind that the order in which the coins are drawn from the bag is still entirely random.

In this best-case scenario, what are the odds that the letters on the coins spell the word "HELLO"?

"""Построение тепловых карт с использованием сплайнов для сглаживания линий
"""

import numpy as np
from scipy.interpolate import CubicSpline


def calculate_midpoint(point_a: float, point_b: float) -> float:
    """
    Вычисляет среднюю точку между двумя точками.

    Args:
        point_a (float): Начальная точка.
        point_b (float): Конечная точка.

    Returns:
        float: Средняя точка.
    """

    return (point_a + point_b) / 2


def create_spline_points(
    cluster: list[list[float]], num_points: int = 100
) -> list[list[float]]:
    """
    Создает сплайн по заданному кластеру точек и возвращает список точек
    на этом сплайне.

    Args:
        cluster (list[list[float]]): Список из трех точек, определяющих сплайн.
        num_points (int, optional): Количество точек на сплайне. По умолчанию 100.

    Returns:
        points (list[list[float]]): Список точек на сплайне.
    """

    x = [point[0] for point in cluster]
    y = [point[1] for point in cluster]
    z = [point[2] for point in cluster]

    # Create cubic splines for x, y, and z coordinates
    spline_x = CubicSpline(x, x)
    spline_y = CubicSpline(x, y)
    spline_z = CubicSpline(x, z)

    # Generate points on the spline
    t = np.linspace(x[0], x[-1], num_points)
    points = [[spline_x(t_i), spline_y(t_i), spline_z(t_i)] for t_i in t]

    return points


if __name__ == "__main__":
    north_point = [0.0, 12.5, 25.0]
    west_point = [12.5, 0.0, 27.0]
    south_point = [25.0, 12.5, 26.0]
    east_point = [12.5, 25.0, 28.0]

    ne_point = [0.0, 25.0, calculate_midpoint(east_point[2], north_point[2])]
    nw_point = [0.0, 0.0, calculate_midpoint(north_point[2], west_point[2])]
    sw_point = [25.0, 0.0, calculate_midpoint(west_point[2], south_point[2])]
    se_point = [25.0, 25.0, calculate_midpoint(south_point[2], east_point[2])]

    ne_north_nw = [ne_point, north_point, nw_point]
    nw_west_sw = [nw_point, west_point, sw_point]
    sw_south_se = [sw_point, south_point, se_point]

    ne_north_nw_points = create_spline_points(ne_north_nw)
    nw_west_sw_points = create_spline_points(nw_west_sw)
    sw_south_se_points = create_spline_points(sw_south_se)

SUBROUTINE SNMB(NM1,NP,XP,YP,XB,XE,IS,IN,*)
      REAL XP(NM1),YP(NM1),D(2),XB(2),XE(2)
      INTEGER IS(10),IS1(10)
      D(1)=XE(1)-XB(1)
      D(2)=XE(2)-XB(2)
      DO 1 I=1,NP
      XP(I)=XP(I)-XB(1)
      YP(I)=YP(I)-XB(2)
  1   CONTINUE
      J=1
      DO 10 I=1,NP-1
      U=XP(I)*D(2)-YP(I)*D(1)
      V=XP(I+1)*D(2)-YP(I+1)*D(1)
      U1=XP(I)*D(1)+YP(I)*D(2)
      V1=XP(I+1)*D(1)+YP(I+1)*D(2)
      IF(U.GE.0..AND.V.LT.0.) THEN
      IF(U1.LT.0..AND.V1.LT.0.) GOTO 10
      IS1(J)=I
      J=J+1
      IF(U1.GT.0..AND.V1.GT.0.) GOTO 2
      END IF
 10   CONTINUE
  2   CONTINUE
      IN=J-1
      J1=1
      DO 30 J=1,IN
      U=XP(IS1(J))-XP(IS1(J)+1)
      V=YP(IS1(J))-YP(IS1(J)+1)
      DET=D(1)*V-D(2)*U
      IF(ABS(DET).LT.1.E-12) RETURN1
      U1=XP(IS1(J))*V-YP(IS1(J))*U
      V1=YP(IS1(J))*D(1)-XP(IS1(J))*D(2)
      T=U1/DET
      S=V1/DET
      IF(T.GE.0..AND.T.LE.1..AND.S.GE.0..AND.S.LE.1.) THEN
      IS(J1)=IS1(J)
      J1=J1+1
      END IF
 30   CONTINUE
      DO 11 I=1,NP
      XP(I)=XP(I)+XB(1)
      YP(I)=YP(I)+XB(2)
 11   CONTINUE
      IN=J1-1
      RETURN
      END

\section*{General formula for $K(t)$ (AccProfitsfix)}
	
	\[
	K(0) = \text{Gewinn\_zu\_Bilanz}
	\]
	For $t \geq 1$,
	\[
	K(t) = K(t-1) + H(t) + 
	\begin{cases} 
		I(t) & \text{if } t \leq 2 \\
		0 & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]
	
	Plugging in the definition of $H(t)$ we get, for $t \geq 1$,
	\[
	K(t) = (1 + F(t))K(t-1) + 
	\begin{cases} 
		\max(AN3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(1) + I(1)  & \text{if } t = 1 \\
		\max(AO3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(2) + I(2)  & \text{if } t = 2 \\
		0 & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]
	
	If we now plug in the definition of $F(t)$, we get:
		\[
	K(t) =
	\begin{cases} 
		(1 + AN3)K(0) + \max(AN3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(1) + I(1) & \text{if } t = 1 \\
		(1 + AO3)K(1) + \max(AO3-RZ, 0) \cdot AS(2) + I(2) & \text{if } t = 2 \\
		K(t-1) & \text{otherwise}
	\end{cases}
	\]
