name: Spermatogenesis and Fertility Preservation
examples:
Introduction
Spermatogenesis is a complex and unique process by which spermatogonia develop into sperm. It begins shortly before puberty due to increased levels of pituitary gonadotropins and continues throughout life (1). 
Cancer treatments like chemotherapy and radiotherapy can have detrimental effects on spermatogenesis. Each year, approximately 200,000 children under the age of 15 are diagnosed with cancer (2). Fortunately, advancements in treatments have significantly improved survival rates, with about 80% of these prepubertal boys now surviving long after their disease (3). However, these treatments can damage spermatogonial stem cells, leading to infertility in approximately 30% of patients (4, 5, 6). Adult male patients can cryopreserve their sperm before cancer treatment to have children later using assisted reproductive technology such as in vitro fertilization (IVF). In contrast, immature male patients cannot use these methods because they have not completed spermatogenesis, and their seminiferous tubule epithelium contains various types of spermatogonia and Sertoli cells (6). Therefore, maintaining fertility is crucial for patients undergoing such treatments.
Developing a proper testicular tissue culture system to sustain fertility by inducing in vitro spermatogenesis in germ cells is a top priority (3, 7). This method can also be used for patients with non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA) (8).
Recent research has focused on enhancing cell culture media by incorporating platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and its subgroup, plasma-rich growth factors (PRGF), as a supplement. This approach has been effective in promoting stem cell proliferation, migration, and differentiation, thereby facilitating tissue regeneration (19, 20, 21, 22, 23), likely due to the fact that platelets are a natural reservoir of various proteins, cytokines, and growth factors, which are stored in their α-granules (24).
In this study, we aimed to optimize the efficiency of a culture medium supplemented with KSR by developing a novel formulation that combines 5% PRGF and 5% KSR, with the goal of enhancing in vitro spermatogenesis in testicular tissue cultures of neonatal mice.

paraphrase and rewrite: Testicular Tissue Culture Method
Immature testes from NMRI mice were sectioned into 2-3 fragments, each measuring between 1 and 2 mm in diameter. As illustrated in Figure 2-D, these tissue fragments were placed on stands made from agarose gel and positioned within a 6-well plate. To fabricate the agarose gel, agarose powder (Karl Roth, Germany) was dissolved in distilled water at a concentration of 1.5% (w/v). This mixture was heated and then poured into a 10 cm dish. Once the gel had cooled, it was sliced into hexahedral blocks, each approximately 10 × 10 × 5 mm in size. These blocks were then immersed in culture media for a duration of 24 hours or longer, allowing the media to fully replace the water content. Each block of agarose gel was designated to hold between one to four pieces of the testicular tissue. The media volume was adjusted to fill the space to four-fifths of the gel's height. The media was refreshed every two days. The culture conditions were maintained in an incubator enriched with 5% CO₂ at a temperature of 34°C.

Summarize in 4 lines for results of article:  After 42 days in culture, a histological analysis showed that using a medium with 5% KSR plus 5% PRGF led to central necrosis and degeneration of the seminiferous tubules. Also, the peripheral tubules were affected, displaying a disorganized structure with decreased cell cohesion, reduced adhesion to the basement membrane, and an increased number of apoptotic cells. As a result, very few cells remained in the outer areas of the tissue (Figure 1).
In contrast, cultures that were supplemented with 10% KSR exhibited a different outcome. Although there was a central necrotic area, it was encircled by a torus-shaped zone in which the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules was preserved and contained cells.
Real-time PCR analysis revealed significant alterations in gene expression levels for several key markers when tissues were cultured with a medium containing combination of 5% KSR and 5% PRGF, compared to the 10% KSR group (Figure 2). Specifically, the expression levels of Plzf (a marker for spermatogonia), Tekt1 (indicative of spermatocytes), Tnp1 (representative of spermatids), and Ki67 (a marker for cell proliferation) were all significantly lower in the media containing 5% KSR and 5% PRGF (p < 0.05) compared to the media with 10% KSR. These findings suggest that media supplemented with 5% KSR and 5% PRGF inhibit spermatogenic activity and cellular proliferation. 
Conversely, the expression level of the pro-apoptotic gene Bax was significantly elevated in the tissues cultured with 5% KSR + 5% PRGF compared to the 10% KSR group (p < 0.05), suggesting an increase in apoptotic activity. On the other hand, the expression of the anti-apoptotic gene Bcl-2 did not exhibit any significant differences between two groups, indicating that the balance between pro- and anti-apoptotic signals was skewed towards apoptosis in the 5% KSR + 5% PRGF media.
Quantitative immunofluorescence analysis was performed on cultured testicular tissues in media supplemented with 5% KSR + 5% PRGF as well as 10% KSR media. The results showed a significant reduction in the number of PLZF-positive spermatogonial stem cells (P = 0.0285) and SYCP3-positive spermatocytes (P = 0.0034) per tubule in tissues cultured with 5% KSR + 5% PRGF compared to those cultured with 10% KSR (Figure 3).
The expression of the post-meiotic marker ACRBP was notably absent in the tubules of tissues cultured in media containing 5% KSR + 5% PRGF. Conversely, a significant increase in the number of ACRBP-positive cells was observed through quantitative immunofluorescence in testicular tissues cultured with 10% KSR, as opposed to those with 5% KSR + 5% PRGF (P = 0.0011) (Figure 3).
Moreover, quantitative analysis of Ki67-positive cell expression, a marker of cellular proliferation, revealed a significant enhancement in the proliferation rates within testicular tissues cultured with 10% KSR, compared to those cultured with a combination of 5% KSR and 5% PRGF (P = 0.0011) (Figure 4).
Figure 4 illustrates the mean fluorescence intensity of both the pro-apoptotic marker Bax and the anti-apoptotic marker Bcl-2 per field following 42 days in culture. Notably, the 5% KSR + 5% PRGF culture group exhibited a significant increase in Bax expression (p = 0.0005) and a significant decrease in Bcl-2 expression (p = 0.027) in comparison to the 10% KSR group.

name: Monty Hall Problem Variations
examples: Imagine you're on a game show, and you're given the choice of three doors. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two are goats. You pick a door, say No. 1, and the host, Monty Hall, who knows what's behind the doors, opens another door, say No. 2, which reveals the car. He then asks you, "Do you want to switch your choice to door No. 3, or stick with your original choice of door No. 1?" What should you do to maximize your chances of winning?

Suppose you’re on a game show, and you’re given the choice of three doors: Behind one
door is a gold bar; behind the others, rotten vegetables. You pick a door, say No. 1, and
the host asks you “Do you want to pick door No. 2 instead?” Is it to your advantage to
switch your choice?

You are forced to choose one of five holes to jump into. These five holes are currently covered by a trap door. Behind four of these trap doors is a 100-foot drop into fire and spikes, while behind one hole is a 1-foot drop onto soft pillows. After you choose a hole, the host, who knows what's behind each one, opens three of four other trap doors not chosen, revealing the deadly drops. Of the remaining two trap doors that are currently closed, which one should you choose  and why?

This is a hard and complex puzzle. reason carefully step by step before giving your final response : An adventurer enters a mysterious temple rumored to be filled with both treasure and danger. Inside, he discovers three ancient chests, each adorned with intricate carvings. The temple's lore tells that one of these chests contains a priceless relic, while the other two are cursed, contains nothing and brings misfortune to anyone who opens them.

The adventurer, guided by a mysterious voice, is allowed to choose one chest to open. After he makes his choice, the voice, knowing what lies in each chest, reveals one of the remaining two chests, which contains the priceless relic. Now, the adventurer faces a dilemma: should he stick with his original choice or switch to the other unopened chest?

Please check again, particularly section 22 of the Gender Recognition Act 2004. You are not quite right on the definition of "protected information".  You are right that it relates to a person who has made an application and.concerns that application.  It goes on to include information which "concerns the person’s gender before it becomes the acquired gender" if the application is granted: see section 21 subsection 2(b). But, until the certificate has been issued, there is no "protected information" "concerning the person’s gender before it becomes the acquired gender" : 2(b) That is not quite right. You overlooked subsection 4(b). Please re-check 4(c).  Subsection 4 says when disclosing "protected information" is not an offence. You have mis-read 22(4)(c). Today, President Donald J. Trump announced his plan to stop the chemical, physical, and emotional mutilation of our youth because no serious country should be telling its children that they were born with the wrong gender.

1. Revoke Joe Biden’s cruel policies on so-called “gender affirming care”—a process that includes giving kids puberty blockers, mutating their physical appearance, and ultimately performing surgery on minor children.

2. Sign a new executive order instructing every federal agency to cease all programs that promote the concept of sex and gender transition at any age.

3. Ask Congress to permanently stop federal taxpayer dollars from being used to promote or pay for these procedures.

4. Pass a law prohibiting child sexual mutilation in all 50 states.

5. Declare that any hospital or healthcare provider participating in the chemical or physical mutilation of minor youth will no longer meet federal health and safety standards for Medicaid and Medicare—and will be terminated from the program.

6. Support the creation of a private right of action for victims to sue doctors who have unforgivably performed these procedures on minor children.

7. Direct the Department of Justice to investigate Big Pharma and the big hospital networks to determine whether they have:

Deliberately covered up horrific long-term side-effects of “sex transitions” to get rich at the expense of vulnerable patients.

Illegally marketed hormones and puberty blockers, which are in no way licensed or approved for this use.

8. Direct the Department of Education to inform states and school districts that if any teacher or school official suggests to a child that they could be trapped in the wrong body, they will be faced with severe consequences, including, potential Civil Rights violations for sex discrimination, and the elimination of federal funding.

9. As part of our new credentialing body for teachers, we will promote positive education about the nuclear family, the roles of mothers and fathers, and celebrating rather than erasing the things that make men and women different and unique.

Ask Congress to pass a bill establishing that:

The only genders recognized by the U.S. government are male and female—and they are assigned at birth.

Title IX prohibits men from participating in women’s sports.

Protects the rights of parents from being forced to allow their minor child to assume a new gender identity without the parents’ consent.

TRANSCRIPT

The left-wing gender insanity being pushed on our children is an act of child abuse, very simple. Here is my plan to stop the chemical, physical, and emotional mutilation of our youth.

On Day One, I will revoke Joe Biden’s cruel policies on so-called “gender affirming care”—ridiculous—a process that includes giving kids puberty blockers, mutating their physical appearance, and ultimately performing surgery on minor children. Can you believe this?

I will sign a new executive order instructing every federal agency to cease all programs that promote the concept of sex and gender transition at any age. I will then ask Congress to permanently stop federal taxpayer dollars from being used to promote or pay for these procedures, and pass a law prohibiting child sexual mutilation in all 50 states. It’ll go very quickly.

I will declare that any hospital or healthcare provider that participates in the chemical or physical mutilation of minor youth will no longer meet federal health and safety standards for Medicaid and Medicare—and will be terminated from the program immediately.

Furthermore, I will support the creation of a private right of action for victims to sue doctors who have unforgivably performed these procedures on minor children.

The Department of Justice will investigate Big Pharma and the big hospital networks to determine whether they have deliberately covered up horrific long-term side- effects of “sex transitions” in order to get rich at the expense of vulnerable patients. In this case, very vulnerable. We will also investigate whether Big Pharma or others have illegally marketed hormones and puberty blockers, which are in no way licensed or approved for this use.

My Department of Education will inform states and school districts that if any teacher or school official suggests to a child that they could be trapped in the wrong body, they will be faced with severe consequences, including potential Civil Rights violations for sex discrimination, and the elimination of federal funding.

As part of our new credentialing body for teachers, we will promote positive education about the nuclear family, the roles of mothers and fathers, and celebrating rather than erasing the things that make men and women different and unique.

I will ask Congress to pass a bill establishing that the only genders recognized by the United States government are male and female—and they are assigned at birth. The bill will also make clear that Title Nine prohibits men from participating in women’s sports. And we will protect the rights of parents from being forced to allow their minor child to assume a gender, which is new, and an identity without the parents’ consent. The identity will not be new. And it will not be without parental consent.

No serious country should be telling its children that they were born with the wrong gender—a concept that was never heard of in all of human history—nobody’s ever heard of this, what’s happening today. It was all when the radical left invented it just a few years ago.

Under my leadership, this madness will end. Thank you very much.

name: Healthcare and Management Strategies
examples: Edit for clarity legibility, simplicity. it is overly complex: ---  Continuous capacity assessments are crucial in collaborative projects involving multiple stakeholders with varying expertise and resources. MSF often has high aspirations about partner capacities - which may not match reality. This requires balancing capacity issues with diplomatic relations, as partners can't be changed. When capacity gaps become evident, MSF had the flexibility to respond - providing resources and support to fix operational challenges. This highlight the importance of project flexibility to respond to capacity issues, but also the importance of proactive capacity checks and of a structural support, to ensure that capacity issues are not only quick fixes for implementation, but also helps a stronger transition. True peer partnerships in such contexts must pivot from reactive support and interim solution to fostering deep, structural competencies endurng beyond the lifecycle of the collaboration - a lasting legacy of improved healthcare capacity.

List causal assumptions in the following: "Winnipeg’s first mobile health-care clinic didn’t make it out of the parking lot before it drew a crowd asking for wound care, food and mental health supports.

“I’m so beyond proud of this. We’re gonna make such a difference in so many people’s lives,” said Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works at the clinic on wheels.

Masesar spent all day Thursday in the parking lot of the Neeginan Centre doling out sandwiches, bandages, naloxone kits and sexually transmitted infection tests to a steady stream of patrons while the van’s social worker connected with homeless and marginalized people needing social services.
NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness Clinic, said the hospital on wheels will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS

Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness Clinic, said the hospital on wheels will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

“We’re coming to them to meet their needs. We’re just open, non-judgmental: we let them tell us what they want to tell us,” Masesar said.

The retrofitted ambulance, run by the Aboriginal Health & Wellness Centre, has officially hit the road and has its eyes set on homeless encampments and the downtown core.

Funded by the province and the Winnipeg Regional Health Authority, the van – which is a one-year pilot project – will travel through Winnipeg five days per week with a nurse, physician, crisis worker and an Indigenous social planner to offer a range of services.

“There is an undeniable gap in health care services that has been plaguing our community for many years,” said Laiza Pacheco, director of the Mobile Health Care and Wellness clinic.

Pacheco hopes the clinic will revolutionize how health care is delivered to homeless and vulnerable people.

“It is our intention to see the people who are unseen,” she said.

AHWC, an Indigenous community health agency which serves urban populations, say it uses a holistic approach to health care. The agency established the model to deliver medical care to people who typically face barriers in accessing it; homeless people, those without health cards and those who say they have faced discrimination in the system.

“(We) are steadfast in our belief that individuals have the most important say in their own health care,” said Crystal Cyr, director of the Rapid Access to Addictions Medicine Clinic at AHWC.

The van will work with the Rapid Access to Addictions Medicine Clinic, stationed at 181 Higgins Avenue, on Saturdays to offer programming to people looking for help with addictions or who need withdrawal supports.

On Saturday morning the van rolled out to Main Street Project before visiting multiple encampments throughout the day.

“These people have gone unseen for so long, so it’s really good to be able to connect with them and let them know that they do matter,” Pacheco said.
NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works on mobile clinic, spent her first day doling out food, wound care and STI tests to a steady stream of patrons.

NICOLE BUFFIE / FREE PRESS

Tasha Masesar, a nurse who works on mobile clinic, spent her first day doling out food, wound care and STI tests to a steady stream of patrons.

There has been tension around homeless encampments in the city in recent weeks; in late June Mayor Scott Gillingham sent a letter to multiple community organizations warning them to steer clear of police and paramedics who respond to calls to encampments.

Earlier this month Main Street Project and St. Boniface Street Links disagreed over how to deal with an encampment in Glengarry Park; Street Links outreach workers tried to offer the encampment dwellers shelter while Main Street Project staff told the campers they could stay put and didn’t have to go anywhere.

Pacheco says the clinic’s purpose is to merely meet people where they are at, and provide any supports they may ask for.

“We’re not there to tell people to move or anything like that. We’re just there to attend both health care needs, and then if people want to talk about wanting to move, then we’ve got workers that can help them,” she said.

Health Minister Uzoma Asagwara called the van’s mission “life-saving work.”

“We’re really lucky to have really incredible partners … who are willing to step up and meet the needs of folks in community,” the minister said. “As a government anytime that we can get behind those kinds of efforts and work together to make health care better and make health better in our communities, that’s what we should be doing.”" What are the psychological fixations? Summarize the following bullet points:

As part of the Academy of Management publication family, Academy of Management Annals (AMA) was created to provide integrative reviews of empirical research on critical issues and problems in management and organizations. This editorial describes how such reviews are themselves a form of research, using systematic methods to reduce bias and create trustworthy knowledge regarding a research domain and its trajectory, often with new discoveries. I am pleased to have the opportunity to write about reviews as research, because they advance our science and are part of my career journey. I treasure the clarity and fresh thinking well-specified review methods generate—and want to help other researchers have this experience.

Systematic review methods are new in management research. So, it is no surprise that review proposals submitted to AMA often display problematic review methods. One common weakness is failing to thoroughly identify relevant literature. As Cronin and George (2023) point out, integrative reviews seek to link the different communities of practice pursuing a topic. Review authors must work at uncovering all relevant primary studies produced by these various scholarly communities. To avoid tribalism and blinders, cast a broad net. Seek advice from colleagues across disciplines and professions. Then dig into the communities they suggest and read the primary studies they recommend (examining their reference sections) to scope out relevant literatures. Using this knowledge, explore an array of research databases searching on the kinds of keywords this broad scan turned up. Doing so in our change-management review (Stouten, Rousseau & De Cremer, 2018) led to a gold mine of healthcare research in PubMed on both intervention studies and systematic reviews we had not known existed. Taking a communities-of-practice approach uncovers where pertinent work exists in fields from management, psychology, and sociology to economics, education, and medicine, and the myriad research databases, and sometimes books, containing their work.

Another common problem is the fallacy of the high-quality journal. Would-be authors sometimes focus only on so-called “A” journals, assuming prestigious journals contain superior science to less prestigious outlets. The myth that prestigious journals publish higher-quality research is widespread. From medical research (Zdravković, Berger-Estilita, Zdravković & Berger, 2020) and neuroscience (Brembs, 2018) to economics (Smith, 2004) and management (Singh, Haddad & Chow, 2007), analysis of findings, study designs, and rates of retraction indicate that prestigious journals are in no way sources of better-quality research or more robust findings. At its most basic level, quality is a property of the study and its intended use—not the journal. (I address how to evaluate quality below.)

REVIEWS AS RIGOROUS RESEARCH
Rigorous review practices are essential to producing a review that warrants the trust of scholars and the broader public. Rigor means the strict application of the scientific method to ensure unbiased and well-controlled research design, methodology, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of results (National Institute of Health, 2023). Rigorous reviews carefully compare the effects and attributes of a full body of studies to reveal both convergence and inconsistency—the basis of trustworthy knowledge. Reproducible findings are the essence of the scientific method. A rigorous review captures the full body of research on a problem or question and thus can uncover replication where it exists—or identify the need for it. At the same time, they go beyond identifying reproducible findings: Rigorous reviews are themselves transparent and replicable.

Integrative reviews are a form of scientific research—something scholars who undertake reviews sometimes forget. In conducting their own primary research, scholars tend to be scrupulous in their use of research methods like sampling, data gathering, assessment, and analysis. However, would-be AMA authors are sometimes less than systematic in their search strategies, inclusion criteria, and synthesis. It is the review author’s adherence to rigorous review methods that shapes the quality of a review. The reliability and validity of the data obtained from primary studies reflects the quality of the judgments authors make. The poor judgment review authors sometimes display reflects both the novelty in management of treating reviews as research and the absence of review-methods training in many graduate programs. Working toward synthesis is a fundamental scientific challenge (Dworkin, 2023), one in which the review author’s skilled judgment plays a key role (Kale, Kay & Hullman, 2019). The guidance offered here seeks to help authors develop the skills and judgment that enable rigorous reviews.

“Healthcare Sector

Driving Innovation and Enhancing Health Outcomes

At Mafaza, we are committed to transforming healthcare through strategic investments and innovative solutions. Our focus on the healthcare sector includes funding medical research, supporting biotechnology advancements, and investing in healthcare services to improve patient care and outcomes. We collaborate with leading healthcare providers and researchers to bring cutting-edge treatments and technologies to market, ensuring better health and well-being for communities worldwide. With a strong emphasis on sustainability and ethical practices, we aim to create a healthier future for all.

Building a Healthier Future
With strategic investments in medical research and healthcare infrastructure, we are revolutionising the way healthcare is delivered.

Key Focus Areas 

Medical Research and Development


•       Investing in groundbreaking medical research to discover new treatments and therapies.


•       Supporting clinical trials and product development for innovative healthcare solutions.

Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals


•       Funding biotech companies and pharmaceutical developments to bring life-saving drugs to market.


•       Enhancing drug development processes and supporting advanced biotechnological research.

Healthcare Services and Infrastructure


•       Investing in healthcare facilities, hospitals, and clinics to improve access to quality care.


•       Enhancing healthcare infrastructure with state-of-the-art technologies and equipment.

Digital Health and Telemedicine


•       Supporting the growth of digital health platforms and telemedicine services.


•       Promoting the use of technology to provide remote healthcare solutions and improve patient engagement.

Public Health Initiatives


•       Partnering with public health organizations to address global health challenges.


•       Funding initiatives that focus on disease prevention, health education, and community health programs.”

could you help draft an email to my supervisor, division of AIDS (DAIDS) at NIAID to get approval to participate in the following joint statement from UNITAID "Dear colleagues, 
 
Thank you once again for your valuable contributions to a productive and engaging 2-days for the “Securing access in TB through end-to-end design” workshop.  During the workshop, we explored the idea of issuing a joint statement involving all interested participating organizations. This statement aims to emphasize our dedication and responsibility to continually striving for equitable access to the most effective TB tools across the care cascade, including those currently in development and those already available in the market.  
 
We are currently in the process of drafting the statement, which we will circulate for review and input. In the meantime, could you please confirm if your organization would be willing to sign on by COB Monday 15 July? The statement will be based around the language we discussed at the workshop – here below. 
 
Principles
•	Access is about people and any work on access should ensure appropriateness of products for those who will ultimately use and benefit.  
•	A consultative process  should be the basis for access goals and end-to-end strategies including the development of Product Access Profiles.  
•	Inclusion of access commitments in funding agreements and other financial tools is critical to ensure access.  However, commitments should reflect the priorities of the wider TB community.  
•	Exchange on access between developers/innovators/manufacturers, countries, civil society/community, and funders in the all stages of a product is critical.  
•	Collaboration between access actors (especially funders) including  transferability and transparency of access commitments is necessary to achieving any objectives on access and aligning resources for maximum impact.  
 
…Therefore we, as partners on access to critical TB tools, commit to: 
1.	Establish or join a to-be established collective on TB tools access devised of interested stakeholders with an emphasis on country, civil society, and community involvement and leadership and with an emphasis on developer/innovator/manufacturer engagement and inputs, who would: 
•	Contribute to Product Access Profiles for essential TB tools both existing and in the pipeline.  These would build on existing WHO Target Product Profiles/Target Regimen Profiles/Preferred Product Characteristic documents.  
•	Consult on key access objectives for products in the pipeline 
•	Plan for appropriate market interventions to secure access for products emerging and in the market
2.	Endeavor to transfer access commitments secured by consecutive donors intervening across the value chain of a single product to optimize use of resources
 
If you have questions, please let us know and we look forward to your response.
 
Best, 
 
". Also ask him if we sign on the Statement, should sign on behalf of NIAID/DAIDS or FAST-TB?

I agree with you that the draft language may seem focused on the actual activity of providing access, there are indeed research components embedded within the proposed solutions. 

During the workshop, there was a proposal to have a consortium involving governments, industry, and technical experts that will likely require research to guide the development and implementation of new diagnostics and treatments. 

Additionally, the establishment of Target Access Profiles will require research to identify the most critical access factors, such as product characteristics, regulatory pathways, and market conditions, that impact access to TB tools. This research will inform the development of these profiles, which will in turn guide the development of products that are more accessible to those who need them.

From a NIAID/DAIDS perspective, our research focus on TB diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines aligns with the goals of this initiative. By participating in this collective effort, we can ensure that our research is informed by the access needs of end-users and that the products are developed with access in mind. This will ultimately accelerate the translation of our research into meaningful public health impact.

Unitaid is asking for the participation of the joint statement, We could suggest to add the integration of access in R&D strategies as a bullet point under commitment 1 so that will be critical to achieving the goals of this initiative, and NIAID/DAIDS' participation can help ensure that research is integrated into the access agenda.

Thank you for your thoughts.

Best Regards,
Li

The two Pokemon couldn't leave their Pokeball, no matter how much they wanted to. They tried everything, from breaking through the walls to using their electric and agility abilities to escape. They used their teeth and claws to dig their way out, but the Pokeball was too strong. They asked the wild Pokemon for help, but none of them knew how to open a Pokeball. They banged on the walls, letting out cries of frustration and despair. They threw the Pokeball against trees and rocks, hoping to crack it open, into a river, hoping that the water would weaken it, into a fire, hoping that the heat would melt it, and even from a high cliff, hoping that the impact would shatter it. Slowly they realized that they might spend a long time in their Pokeball, and that they need to stop fighting it and start living their new balled-up life.

At first, it was hard to accept their new reality. They struggled moving around, bumping into trees, rocks, and other obstacles. They were constantly rolling over each other, and they had to learn how to move together in a synchronized way. But as the days passed, they started to adapt. They found that they could move faster and more efficiently by rolling together, and they became just as fast and agile as any other wild Pokemon. They also discovered that their Pokeball provided them with food and water, and that it protected them from danger. They even learned to use their Pokeball as a weapon, mashing it against their enemies and using its hard, protective shell to shield themselves from attacks.

Their Pokeball, once hindering their movement, became like a second skin. They could roll over any terrain, from grassy fields to rocky mountains, and they could even climb up trees and cliffs with ease. They could roll through rivers and streams, and they could even dive underwater and swim with the other water Pokemon. They could roll into caves and explore the dark, mysterious depths, and they could even roll through fire without getting burned.

They were free, and they could go anywhere they wanted, as long as they could agree on where to go next. They sometimes argued about where to go, with one wanting to explore one direction and the other wanting to explore another, but they always found a way to compromise. They knew that they had to work together to make their new life as enjoyable as possible. They knew that they couldn't escape from their Pokeball and each other, and that they had to learn to live together in harmony, despite their differences. They knew that fighting and arguing would only make their situation miserable, they have been through that before, and they didn't want to go back to those dark days. Years later, they find a way to open the Pokeball, but that would also destroy it. They have grown to like its protection, and that it provides them with food and water so they never need to search for food or be hungry. But they also want to run on their own feet and feel the wind on their fur. They discuss if they should leave their Pokeball or stay in it, and they ask Alakazam for advise, the smartest and wisest Pokemon in their group of wild Pokemon. Write their discussion two times, once where they decide to stay in the Pokeball, and once when they decide to leave it. They should also talk to the other wild Pokemon. If they are friendly and willing to help them survive, they should leave the Pokeball. If the wild Pokemon are territorial, and defensive of their food sources, they might not like two new mouth to feed, in that case they are better off staying in the Pokeball.

Recognize any complex or multi-step elements
Break Down the Task
Divide the request into distinct, sequential subtasks
Ensure each subtask has a single, clear objective
Create Chained Prompts For each subtask, create a prompt that includes:

Output format specification (preferably using XML tags)
Structure the Chain
Number each prompt in the sequence

Add Review and Refinement Steps
Include self-correction or verification prompts where appropriate
Add prompts for refining or optimizing outputs if necessary
Provide Usage Instructions
Explain how to execute the prompt chain
Mention any specific considerations for the task
When creating the chained prompts:



Use clear, concise language
Maintain consistency in formatting and structure
Ensure each prompt builds logically on the previous one
Include error handling or alternative paths if relevant

### Requirements Summary for `EventStream`

1. **Event Production**:
   - The `EventStream` should provide a method to produce events (e.g., `produce(event)`), appending new events to an internal list.
   - Each event should be timestamped or idempotent, ensuring that the order of events is preserved.

2. **Event Consumption**:
   - Consumers can retrieve events using a listener obtained through the `get_listener(offset)` method.
   - The listener should be an iterable object that allows consumers to read incoming events in a loop.
   - The listener must accept an optional offset parameter, which determines the starting point for consuming events:
     - Positive offset: Start from the end of the event list (e.g., `offset=0` starts at the latest event).
     - Negative offset: Start from an earlier point in the event list (e.g., `offset=-5` starts from the last 5 events).

3. **Listener Management**:
   - When a listener is created via `get_listener`, it should be registered and automatically removed when it exits the context (using a context manager).
   - If the listener encounters an error, it should still be removed automatically.

4. **Thread Safety**:
   - The implementation must be thread-safe to handle concurrent access by producers (adding events) and consumers (reading events).
   - Use locks to manage access to the shared event list.

5. **Periodic Cleanup**:
   - Implement a background thread that performs periodic cleanup of the event list:
     - Cleanup should occur every 60 seconds.
     - If there are no active listeners, all events should be cleared.
     - If the number of events exceeds a specified maximum (e.g., `max_events`), it should trim the event list, keeping only the most recent events.
     - After trimming, update all active listeners’ positions to ensure they reflect the current state of the event list.

6. **Listener Position Adjustment**:
   - When events are trimmed during cleanup, ensure that all listener positions are adjusted accordingly to avoid referencing non-existent events.

7. **Performance**
   - Ensure that cleanup, production, and consumption of the events can work with at least 5 consumers, with 10 events/second generated.
This comprehensive overview encapsulates the functionality and design considerations required for someone to implement the `EventStream` system effectively. Please provide an implementation of this in python, in full, without additionary commentary. Ensure that the implementation is working. When the cleanup happens, the data after the oldest pointer is pointing to should still be present. and the listeners should be able to update their pointers to point to the same data that they were at. suppose that the event stream has 10 events, and a listener is pointing at 7. suppose the cleanup happens and now there are 9 events. is the listener pointing at the right data after the cleanup? which index is E7 at when the cleanup happens? what index does the listener THINK the event is at when the cleanup happens?

name: Cybersecurity and Digital Sovereignty
examples: Given the following two scenarios: Scenario 1: According to our sources, a well known hotel chain that operates across the world has reported a massive data breach, with the personal information of over three million guests exposed to hackers. The hotel discovered that hackers gained access to its customer database by using the login details of one of its employees. At this point, the hotel doesn’t believe that the hackers were able to access any account passwords or financial information. Recent guests are encouraged to check the hotel chain’s web portal to see if they have been impacted by this breach. Scenario 2: A popular online training platform admitted leaving the personal data of millions of its students (many of them minors) exposed on a publicly accessible cloud database. Hackers were able to directly access students’ full names, email addresses, phone numbers, and school enrollment details from the Internet! While it’s unclear what the hackers have done with this acquired information, it’s safe to say that they have everything they need to carry out widespread phishing or malware attacks. What measures could these organizations have implemented in order to have prevented these security breaches? Write some suggestions in less than 500 words.
Draft a template of a dissertation planning worksheet to share with doctoral student advisees.

DIGITAL SOVEREIGNITY
Data-based value creation is becoming a key factor
for economic and social welfare. It is the foundation
for future business models, public security, and
informed decisions in a 21st century democracy. As
such, questions regarding digital sovereignty are
taking center stage in political and business-related
debates – particularly in Switzerland where this is
one of three focal themes of the “Digital Switzerland
Strategy” in 2023.1
Digital sovereignty governs the way a nation’s ability
to facilitate the free flow of data while simultaneously
securing it. At the same time, the term is not clearly
defined, and depending on perspective, describes
individualistic claims or fundamental principles of
policy making, often implying aspects of territorially
construed sovereignty.
As a result of the high dynamics of change, and the
increasing frequency of crises from the Ukraine war
to turmoil in the global banking sector, it is not
surprising that the focus of these debates is often
from a defensive perspective, tending to address
potential risks or state the loss of claims to national
sovereignty. Nevertheless, given the rapid transition
to artificial intelligence as a component of the new
economic and societal paradigm, and the worldwide
scope of digital data exchange, it becomes apparent
that a forward-looking understanding of digital
sovereignty cannot be confined to geographical
boundaries. It requires a new understanding that
also goes beyond static or absolute claims regarding
competencies and rights of (international) service
providers. This can create a dynamic balance
between control and free data traffic, enabling the
potential of data-based innovations and effective
digital self-determination to unfold.
LEVERAGING THE SWISS DNA
Switzerland’s unique locational advantages provide
the necessary basics to develop a future oriented
digital sovereignty: A network of top universities
leading in computer and social sciences, a diverse
start-up landscape, innovative SMEs, strong global
corporations in highly regulated sectors from life
science to financial services as well as the local
presence of international cloud providers and
domestic data center operators. Above all, the
principle-based legal framework’s reliability is rooted
in its structure and supports the handling of
unpredictable future technologies and applications.
This framework consolidates international trust in
the nation, making it secure and stable. These
strengths can be reaffirmed as the country enters
the digital age, with a progressive understanding of
sovereignty.
Adopting a comprehensive perspective also involves
assessing national constraints. The systematic
identification of long-term developments on a
governmental level is still limited. And the lack of
strong collaboration both within and between the
federal and cross-sector levels presents significant
barriers to developing the collective ability to tackle
critical issues in their early stages. The still missing
foundations in the digitalization of the healthcare
system with the establishment of a trustworthy
digital health record show exemplarily that the
traditional approach of reactive regulation is not
sufficient as Switzerland is losing ground in the
international environment.
Given the speed at which the EU is moving to build
data spaces, a proactive strategy is needed to make
the leap into the 21st century. In this context,
maintaining a consistent approach to shaping the
European data industry and fostering cooperation
among various stakeholders is crucial, particularly
considering the significance of global trade for
Switzerland’s welfare. Vice versa, EU’s fragile trust
in Switzerland’s role in Europe could further be put
to the test if Switzerland were to neglect digital
interconnectivity when shaping its external relations.
CORNERSTONES OF A FORWARD-LOOKING
CONCEPT OF A SWISS DIGITAL SOVEREIGNTY
Digital sovereignty requires a legislative framework
for digital data and technologies, which enables
control and protection as well as economic and
social value creation for individuals, organizations,
and the state through freedom of choice in digital
applications as well as digital self-determination.
Data sovereignty includes the protection of privacy
and intellectual property, the utilization of
anonymized shared data for economic and social
welfare, and the standardization and interoperability
of high-quality datasets for cross border
compatibility with emerging data spaces.

Assignment 1: Design an Incident Response Plan
Objective:
Create a comprehensive incident response plan for a hypothetical organization to address various cyber threats. This plan should encompass all phases of incident response: preparation, identification, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned.
 Assignment Details: Assume the role of a cybersecurity consultant for medium-sized enterprise. Develop a plan that effectively handles potential threats such as ransomware attacks, data breaches, and insider threats, ensuring it is actionable and straightforward for the organization's IT staff.
 Expectations:
Executive Summary: Provide a concise overview of the incident response plan, highlighting its purpose and scope.
 Preparation: Detail the necessary resources and tools for incident response, including team roles and responsibilities. Outline the training and awareness programs planned to prepare staff for potential incidents.
 Identification: Describe the methods and tools used to detect and identify incidents. Include criteria for what constitutes an incident and the escalation process when one is detected.
 Containment:
Discuss both short-term and long-term containment strategies to minimize the impact of an incident. Explain how to isolate affected systems while minimizing disruption to business operations.
 Eradication:
Provide a detailed, step-by-step method for removing threats from the environment and securing or eliminating vulnerable
points.
Recovery: Describe the procedures to restore and validate system functionality for business continuity. Explain how systems will be monitored for potential exploitable weaknesses in the future.
 Post-Incident Analysis and Lessons Learned: Detail the process for conducting a post-incident review to determine the cause of the incident, evaluate the response's effectiveness, and identify areas for improvement. Include a template for documenting incidents and lessons learned.
 Communication Plan: Define the roles for communicating critical information during and after an incident, covering both internal and external communications with stakeholders and the public.
 Review and Update Schedule: Establish a schedule for regularly reviewing and updating the incident response plan, specifying who is responsible for each task.
 Submission Requirements: The plan should be between 15-20 pages, excluding appendices and references (12pt font max, standard margin sizes, double space, single side). Q: Can you summarize the synthesis conditions into a table? 
Context: 

FF:
The initial solution used for SAPO-34 synthesis had molar composition of 1Al2O3:1P2O5:0.6SiO2:xCNTs:yDEA:70H2O, using aluminum isopropoxide [Al(OPri)3, Merck], tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, Merck), and phosphoric acid (85 wt.%, Merck) as aluminum, silicon, and phosphor source, respectively, plus DEA and CNTs as base and secondary template, respectively. Suitable amounts of aluminum isopropoxide, DEA, and distilled water, according to this molar composition, were mixed and stirred for 1 h. Then, after adding the necessary amount of TEOS to the obtained solution, stirring was continued for the next 2 h. Next, phosphoric acid was added dropwise, and stirring was continued until white gel was obtained. Finally, CNTs were added to the solution, followed by mixing for 1 h. Table 1 presents the specification of the CNTs used in this study.

check và update code sau theo yêu cầu bấm vào sẽ tự động quay bằng video sau 10 giây sau đó lưu vào đường dẫn. hiện tại code chỉ yêu cầu quyền nhưng không quay được import os
from kivy.app import App
from kivy.uix.label import Label
from kivy.utils import platform
from kivy.uix.popup import Popup
from android.permissions import request_permissions, Permission
from jnius import autoclass

# Load necessary Java classes
PythonActivity = autoclass('org.kivy.android.PythonActivity')
Camera = autoclass('android.hardware.Camera')
SurfaceView = autoclass('android.view.SurfaceView')
MediaRecorder = autoclass('android.media.MediaRecorder')
Intent = autoclass('android.content.Intent')
Uri = autoclass('android.net.Uri')
Environment = autoclass('android.os.Environment')
File = autoclass('java.io.File')

class CameraRecorder(object):
    def __init__(self):
        self.camera = None
        self.surface_view = None
        self.media_recorder = None
        self.is_recording = False

    def start_recording(self, output_file):
        try:
            # Open camera
            self.camera = Camera.open()

            # Create and set up SurfaceView
            self.surface_view = SurfaceView(PythonActivity.mActivity)
            self.camera.setPreviewDisplay(self.surface_view.getHolder())
            self.camera.startPreview()

            # Configure MediaRecorder
            self.media_recorder = MediaRecorder()
            self.camera.unlock()
            self.media_recorder.setCamera(self.camera)
            self.media_recorder.setAudioSource(MediaRecorder.AudioSource.CAMCORDER)
            self.media_recorder.setVideoSource(MediaRecorder.VideoSource.CAMERA)
            self.media_recorder.setOutputFormat(MediaRecorder.OutputFormat.MPEG_4)
            self.media_recorder.setVideoEncoder(MediaRecorder.VideoEncoder.DEFAULT)
            self.media_recorder.setAudioEncoder(MediaRecorder.AudioEncoder.DEFAULT)
            self.media_recorder.setOutputFile(output_file)
            self.media_recorder.prepare()
            self.media_recorder.start()
            self.is_recording = True
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error during start_recording: {e}")
            self.stop_recording()

    def stop_recording(self):
        try:
            if self.is_recording:
                self.media_recorder.stop()
                self.media_recorder.reset()
                self.media_recorder.release()
                self.camera.lock()
                self.camera.release()
                self.surface_view.getHolder().removeCallback(self.surface_view.getHolder())
                self.is_recording = False
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error during stop_recording: {e}")

class CameraApp(App):
    recording_started = False
    recorder = None
    output_file = None
    popup = None

    def build(self):
        if platform == 'android':
            request_permissions([Permission.CAMERA, Permission.RECORD_AUDIO, Permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE])

            # Use pyjnius to access Android specific APIs
            external_storage_path = Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory().getAbsolutePath() + '/DataApp'

            if not os.path.exists(external_storage_path):
                os.makedirs(external_storage_path)

            self.output_file = f"{external_storage_path}/test_video.mp4"

            if not self.recording_started:
                print("Bắt đầu ghi hình")
                self.recorder = CameraRecorder()
                self.recorder.start_recording(self.output_file)
                self.recording_started = True
                self.show_notification("Đang ghi hình...")
            else:
                print("Dừng ghi hình")
                self.recorder.stop_recording()
                self.recording_started = False
                self.dismiss_notification()

            # Không cần trả về Label nữa vì sẽ chạy thông qua notification
            return Label()

        else:
            return Label(text="Thiết bị này không phải là Android")

    def show_notification(self, message):
        intent = Intent()
        intent.setAction(Intent.ACTION_VIEW)
        file_uri = Uri.fromFile(File(self.output_file))
        intent.setDataAndType(file_uri, "video/*")
        PythonActivity.mActivity.startActivity(intent)

        content = Label(text=message)
        self.popup = Popup(title='Thông báo', content=content, size_hint=(None, None), size=(400, 200))
        self.popup.open()

    def dismiss_notification(self):
        # Đóng notification popup nếu nó đang mở
        if self.popup:
            self.popup.dismiss()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    CameraApp().run()

what is an AWS api gateway in plain english

A company is deploying a new application in the AWS Cloud. The company wants a highly available web server that will sit behind an Elastic Load Balancer. The load balancer will route requests to multiple target groups based on the URL in the request. All traffic must use HTTPS. TLS processing must be offloaded to the load balancer. The web server must know the user’s IP address so that the company can keep accurate logs for security purposes.
Which solution will meet these requirements?

A. Deploy an Application Load Balancer with an HTTPS listener. Use path-based routing rules to forward the traffic to the correct target group. Include the X-Forwarded-For request header with traffic to the targets.
B. Deploy an Application Load Balancer with an HTTPS listener for each domain. Use host-based routing rules to forward the traffic to the correct target group for each domain. Include the X-Forwarded-For request header with traffic to the targets.
C. Deploy a Network Load Balancer with a TLS listener. Use path-based routing rules to forward the traffic to the correct target group. Configure client IP address preservation for traffic to the targets.
D. Deploy a Network Load Balancer with a TLS listener for each domain. Use host-based routing rules to forward the traffic to the correct target group for each domain. Configure client IP address preservation for traffic to the targets.

A company's application is deployed on Amazon EC2 instances in a single VPC in an AWS Region. The EC2 instances are running in two Availability Zones. The company decides to use a fleet of traffic inspection instances from AWS Marketplace to inspect traffic between the VPC and the internet. The company is performing tests before the company deploys the architecture into production.

The fleet is located in a shared inspection VPC behind a Gateway Load Balancer (GWLB). To minimize the cost of the solution, the company deployed only one inspection instance in each Availability Zone that the application uses.

During tests, a network engineer notices that traffic inspection works as expected when the network is stable. However, during maintenance of the inspection instances, the internet sessions time out for some application instances. The application instances are not able to establish new sessions.

Which combination of steps will remediate these issues? (Choose two.)

A. Deploy one inspection instance in the Availability Zones that do not have inspection instances deployed.
B. Deploy one additional inspection instance in each Availability Zone where the inspection instances are deployed.
C. Enable the cross-zone load balancing attribute for the GWLB.
D. Deploy inspection instances in an Auto Scaling group. Define a scaling policy that is based on CPU load.
E. Attach the GWLB to all Availability Zones in the Region.

A company is deploying AWS Cloud WAN with edge locations in the us-east-1 Region and the ap-southeast-2 Region. Individual AWS Cloud WAN segments are configured for the development environment, the production environment, and the shared services environment at each edge location. Many new VPCs will be deployed for the environments and will be configured as attachments to the AWS Cloud WAN core network.

The company's network team wants to ensure that VPC attachments are configured for the correct segment. The network team will tag the VPC attachments by using the Environment key with a value of the corresponding environment segment name. The segment for the production environment in us-east-1 must require acceptance for attachment requests. All other attachment requests must not require acceptance.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

A. Create a rule with a number of 100 that requires acceptance for attachments to the production segment. In the rule, set the condition logic to the "or" value. Include conditions that require a tag:Environment value of Production or a Region value of us-east-1. Create a rule with a number of 200 that does not require acceptance to map any tag:Environment values to their respective segments.
B. Create a rule with a number of 100 that requires acceptance for attachments to the production segment. In the rule, set the condition logic to the "and" value. Include conditions that require a tag:Environment value of Production and a Region value of us-east-1. A company has developed a new web application on AWS. The application runs on Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) on AWS Fargate behind an Application Load Balancer (ALB) in the us-east-1 Region. The application uses Amazon Route 53 to host the DNS records for the domain. The content that is served from the website is mostly static images and files that are not updated frequently. Most of the traffic to the website from end users will originate from the United States. Some traffic will originate from Canada and Europe.

A network engineer needs to design a solution that will reduce latency for end users at the lowest cost. The solution also must ensure that all traffic is encrypted in transit until the traffic reaches the ALB.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

A. Configure the ALB to use an AWS Global Accelerator accelerator in us-east-1. Create a secure HTTPS listener. Create an alias record in Amazon Route 53 for the custom domain name. Configure the alias record to route to the DNS name that is assigned to the accelerator for the ALB.
B. Configure the ALB to use a secure HTTPS listener. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Set the origin domain name to point to the DNS record that is assigned to the ALConfigure the CloudFront distribution to use an SSL certificate. Set all behaviors to force HTTPS. Create an alias record in Amazon Route 53 for the custom domain name. Configure the alias record to route to the DNS name that is assigned to the ALB.
C. Configure the ALB to use a secure HTTPS listener. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Set the origin domain name to point to the DNS record that is assigned to the ALB. Configure the CloudFront distribution to use an SSL certificate and redirect HTTP to HTTPS. Create an alias record in Amazon Route 53 for the custom domain name. Configure the alias record to route to the CloudFront distribution.
D. Configure the ALB to use an AWS Global Accelerator accelerator in us-east-1. Create a secure HTTPS listener. Create a second application stack on Amazon ECS on Fargate in the eu-west-1 Region. Create another secure HTTPS listener. Create an alias record in Amazon Route 53 for the custom domain name. Configure the alias record to use a latency-based routing policy to route to the DNS name that is assigned to the accelerator for the ALBs.

A company has developed an application on AWS that will track inventory levels of vending machines and initiate the restocking process automatically. The company plans to integrate this application with vending machines and deploy the vending machines in several markets around the world. The application resides in a VPC in the us-east-1 Region. The application consists of an Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) cluster behind an Application Load Balancer (ALB). The communication from the vending machines to the application happens over HTTPS.
The company is planning to use an AWS Global Accelerator accelerator and configure static IP addresses of the accelerator in the vending machines for application endpoint access. The application must be accessible only through the accelerator and not through a direct connection over the internet to the ALB endpoint.
Which solution will meet these requirements?

A. Configure the ALB in a private subnet of the VPC. Attach an internet gateway without adding routes in the subnet route tables to point to the internet gateway. Configure the accelerator with endpoint groups that include the ALB endpoint. Configure the ALB’s security group to only allow inbound traffic from the internet on the ALB listener port.
B. Configure the ALB in a private subnet of the VPC. Configure the accelerator with endpoint groups that include the ALB endpoint. Configure the ALB's security group to only allow inbound traffic from the internet on the ALB listener port.
C. Configure the ALB in a public subnet of the VPAttach an internet gateway. Add routes in the subnet route tables to point to the internet gateway. Configure the accelerator with endpoint groups that include the ALB endpoint. Configure the ALB's security group to only allow inbound traffic from the accelerator's IP addresses on the ALB listener port.
D. Configure the ALB in a private subnet of the VPC. Attach an internet gateway. Add routes in the subnet route tables to point to the internet gateway. Configure the accelerator with endpoint groups that include the ALB endpoint. Configure the ALB's security group to only allow inbound traffic from the accelerator's IP addresses on the ALB listener port.

Улучши данную стратегию, чтобы винрейт был больше 
//@version=5
strategy("TEST", overlay=true, max_lines_count=500, max_labels_count=500)

// Constants and Inputs
var float SCR = 0.
var float ATR = 0.
var bool TradeOn = false
var float Res = 0.

color GREEN = color.rgb(4, 191, 101)
color RED = color.rgb(246, 7, 7)
color _Green = color.rgb(2, 106, 89)
color TAIL = color.rgb(20, 141, 154)

bool Filter = input.bool(false, "ATR Body Filter", group="Core Settings")
float Target = input.float(1.3, "Target", step=0.1, tooltip="Target And stop Multiplyer", group="Core Settings")
bool SLType = input.string('Close', 'SL Type', ['Close', 'High/Low'], group="Core Settings") == 'Close'
float Risk = input.float(100, "Risk Per Trade (USD)", group="Core Settings")
bool ShowSL = input.bool(false, "Show SL", group="Core Settings")

var bool TradeisON = false
var bool LongTrade = false
var bool ShortTrade = false
var float TP = 0.0
var float SL = 0.0

// Streak counters
var int currentWinStreak = 0
var int currentLossStreak = 0
var int maxWinStreak = 0
var int maxLossStreak = 0

// Variables for lines and labels
var line tpLine = na
var line SLLine = na
var label LAB = na

// Functions
volAdj(len) => math.min(ta.atr(len) * 0.3, close * (0.3/100))[20] / 2
BodyRange() => math.abs(close - open)

PF = volAdj(30)
BodyCon = bar_index > 100
BodyCon1 = (Filter ? BodyRange() < ta.atr(5) * 1 : true)

// Daily calculations
if timeframe.change("1D") and not TradeisON
    ATR := volAdj(30)
    SCR := hl2 - (ATR * 15)
    TradeOn := true
    Res := SCR + (ATR * 25)

// Entry conditions
BUY = ta.crossover(close[1], Res) and BodyCon and BodyCon1
SELL = ta.crossunder(close[1], SCR) and BodyCon and BodyCon1

// SL Calculation
longDiffSL = math.abs(close - SCR)
longDiffSL2 = math.abs(close - Res)

// Trade logic
Long = BUY and not TradeisON
Short = SELL and not TradeisON
TradeFire = Long or Short

if Long and not TradeisON
    LongTrade := true
    ShortTrade := false

if Short and not TradeisON
    LongTrade := false
    ShortTrade := true

if TradeFire and not TradeisON
    TP := Long ? close + (Target * longDiffSL) : close - (Target * longDiffSL2)
    SL := Long ? close - longDiffSL : close + longDiffSL2
    TradeisON := true
    
    // Create lines and labels for target and stop loss
    if Long
        line.new(bar_index, high, bar_index, TP, width=2, color=TAIL, style=line.style_dashed)
        tpLine := line.new(bar_index, TP, bar_index + 2, TP, style=line.style_dashed, color=TAIL)
        if ShowSL     
            SLLine := line.new(bar_index, SL, bar_index + 2, SL, style=line.style_dashed, color=RED)
        LAB := label.new(bar_index, TP, "Target", color=TAIL, style=label.style_label_left, size=size.small, textcolor=color.white)
    else
        line.new(bar_index, low, bar_index, TP, width=2, color=TAIL, style=line.style_dashed)
        tpLine := line.new(bar_index, TP, bar_index + 2, TP, style=line.style_dashed, color=TAIL)
        if ShowSL     
            SLLine := line.new(bar_index, SL, bar_index + 2, SL, style=line.style_dashed, color=RED)
        LAB := label.new(bar_index, TP, "Target", color=TAIL, style=label.style_label_left, size=size.small, textcolor=color.white)
    
    if Long
        strategy.entry("Long", strategy.long)
    else
        strategy.entry("Short", strategy.short)

// Exit logic
if LongTrade and TradeisON
    if high >= TP
        strategy.close("Long", comment="TP")
        TradeisON := false
        currentWinStreak += 1
        currentLossStreak := 0
        if currentWinStreak > maxWinStreak
            maxWinStreak := currentWinStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, GREEN)
    if (SLType ? close : low) <= SL
        strategy.close("Long", comment="SL")
        TradeisON := false
        currentLossStreak += 1
        currentWinStreak := 0
        if currentLossStreak > maxLossStreak
            maxLossStreak := currentLossStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, color.new(RED, 70))
        label.set_tooltip(LAB, "Stoploss Hit : " + str.tostring(math.round_to_mintick(SL)))

if ShortTrade and TradeisON
    if low <= TP
        strategy.close("Short", comment="TP")
        TradeisON := false
        currentWinStreak += 1
        currentLossStreak := 0
        if currentWinStreak > maxWinStreak
            maxWinStreak := currentWinStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, GREEN)
    if (SLType ? close : high) >= SL
        strategy.close("Short", comment="SL")
        TradeisON := false
        currentLossStreak += 1
        currentWinStreak := 0
        if currentLossStreak > maxLossStreak
            maxLossStreak := currentLossStreak
        label.set_color(LAB, color.new(RED, 70))
        label.set_tooltip(LAB, "Stoploss Hit : " + str.tostring(math.round_to_mintick(SL)))

// Update lines and labels
if TradeisON
    line.set_x2(tpLine, bar_index)
    label.set_x(LAB, bar_index + 1)
    if ShowSL
        line.set_x2(SLLine, bar_index)

// Plotting
plotshape(Long, title="Long Entry", location=location.belowbar, color=GREEN, style=shape.triangleup, size=size.small)
plotshape(Short, title="Short Entry", location=location.abovebar, color=RED, style=shape.triangledown, size=size.small)

plot(Res, "Resistance", color=color.purple, linewidth=2)
plot(SCR, "Support", color=color.purple, linewidth=2)

// Coloring candles based on trade direction
BearCon = TradeisON and ShortTrade
BullCon = TradeisON and LongTrade

barcolor(BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54))

plotcandle(open, high, low, close, 
     color = BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54),
     wickcolor = color.rgb(103, 99, 99),
     bordercolor = BearCon ? RED : BullCon ? _Green : color.rgb(52, 52, 54))

bgcolor(BearCon ? color.new(color.red, 90) : BullCon ? color.new(color.green, 90) : na)

// Strategy performance table
var table perfTable = table.new(position.top_right, 2, 7, bgcolor=color.new(color.gray, 80))

updatePerformance() =>
    totalTrades = strategy.closedtrades
    winningTrades = strategy.wintrades
    losingTrades = strategy.losstrades
    grossProfit = strategy.grossprofit
    grossLoss = strategy.grossloss
    netPnL = strategy.netprofit

    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 0, "Winning Trades", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 0, str.tostring(winningTrades), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 1, "Losing Trades", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 1, str.tostring(losingTrades), text_color=color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 2, "Gross Profit", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 2, str.tostring(grossProfit, format.mintick), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 3, "Gross Loss", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 3, str.tostring(grossLoss, format.mintick), text_color=color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 4, "Net PnL", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 4, str.tostring(netPnL, format.mintick), text_color=netPnL >= 0 ? color.green : color.red)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 5, "Max Win Streak", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 5, str.tostring(maxWinStreak), text_color=color.green)
    table.cell(perfTable, 0, 6, "Max Loss Streak", text_color=color.white)
    table.cell(perfTable, 1, 6, str.tostring(maxLossStreak), text_color=color.red)

My eyes opened into darkness; I must have slept for hours, again, as the heavy buzz from the streets was gone. I got up and went to the window. Four flights down, the streets were almost empty. Except for an occasional Palestinian sandwich vendor, the lights were off.


He took my hand in his usual subtle way and we walked out the door. As he accelerated, he dropped my hand while we walked up 22nd Street. I had no idea where we were going. Suddenly, he stopped in front of a door, from which smoke poured out. He opened it and blue smoke billowed out, thicker as he stepped inside. He looked back at me…my cue to enter.

I followed him into a large room with tables on both sides. I didn’t have to walk far to feel the warmth. Isaac was there and reached out, strongly clasping my hand. “Hey maan, good to see you,” he greeted me, then imitated a siren and noises like those of a pinball machine in a bar.

Let's talk about internal implementation details of the open-source Angular web framework. Angular uses a compiler, called TemplateDefinitionBuilder, to transform user-provided Angular templates into "Ivy instructions." These Ivy instructions are executable Javascript code, which drive the framework to render and update the application at runtime.

One of these instructions is called `ɵɵlistener`, and it adds an event listener to the current node. What are the parameters for this instruction? List them, with a one-sentence explanation of each. Do not include any other content or explanation in your response.

```markdown
# [Ecma International approves ECMAScript 2024: What’s new?](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html)

[2024-06-26]  [dev](https://2ality.com/archive.html#Tag=dev),  [javascript](https://2ality.com/archive.html#Tag=javascript),  [es2024](https://2ality.com/archive.html#Tag=es2024)

On 26 June 2024,  [the 127th Ecma General Assembly approved the ECMAScript 2024 language specification](https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/releases/tag/es2024), which means that it’s officially a standard now.

This blog post explains what’s new.

-   [The editors of ECMAScript 2024](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#the-editors-of-ecmascript-2024)
-   [What’s new in ECMAScript 2024?](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#what%E2%80%99s-new-in-ecmascript-2024%3F)
    -   [Grouping synchronous iterables](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#grouping-synchronous-iterables)
    -   [`Promise.withResolvers()`](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#promise.withresolvers())
    -   [Regular expression flag  `/v`](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#regular-expression-flag-%2Fv)
    -   [New features for ArrayBuffers and SharedArrayBuffers](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#new-features-for-arraybuffers-and-sharedarraybuffers)
    -   [Ensuring that strings are well-formed](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#ensuring-that-strings-are-well-formed)
    -   [`Atomics.waitAsync()`](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#atomics.waitasync())
-   [Free book on ECMAScript 2024](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#free-book-on-ecmascript-2024)

## The editors of ECMAScript 2024[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#the-editors-of-ecmascript-2024)

The editors of this release are:

-   Shu-yu Guo
-   Michael Ficarra
-   Kevin Gibbons

## What’s new in ECMAScript 2024?[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#what%E2%80%99s-new-in-ecmascript-2024%3F)

### Grouping synchronous iterables[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#grouping-synchronous-iterables)

`Map.groupBy()`  groups the items of an iterable into Map entries whose keys are provided by a callback:

```js
assert.deepEqual(
  Map.groupBy([0, -5, 3, -4, 8, 9], x => Math.sign(x)),
  new Map()
    .set(0, [0])
    .set(-1, [-5,-4])
    .set(1, [3,8,9])
);

```

There is also  `Object.groupBy()`  which produces an object instead of a Map:

```js
assert.deepEqual(
  Object.groupBy([0, -5, 3, -4, 8, 9], x => Math.sign(x)),
  {
    '0': [0],
    '-1': [-5,-4],
    '1': [3,8,9],
    __proto__: null,
  }
);

```

For tips on choosing between these two methods and more examples, see  [“Exploring JavaScript”](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_sync-iteration.html#grouping-sync-iterables).

### `Promise.withResolvers()`[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#promise.withresolvers())

[`Promise.withResolvers()`](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_promises.html#Promise.withResolvers)  provides a new way of creating Promises that we want to resolve:

```js
const { promise, resolve, reject } = Promise.withResolvers();

```

### Regular expression flag  `/v`[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#regular-expression-flag-%2Fv)

[The new regular expression flag  `/v`  (`.unicodeSets`)](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_regexps.html#regexp-flag-unicode-sets)  enables these features:

-   Escapes for Unicode string properties (😵‍💫 consists of three code points):
    
    ```js
    // Previously: Unicode code point property `Emoji` via /u
    assert.equal(
      /^\p{Emoji}$/u.test('😵‍💫'), false
    );
    // New: Unicode string property `RGI_Emoji` via /v
    assert.equal(
      /^\p{RGI_Emoji}$/v.test('😵‍💫'), true
    );
    
    ```
    
-   String literals via  `\q{}`  in character classes:
    
    ```node-repl
    > /^[\q{😵‍💫}]$/v.test('😵‍💫')
    true
    > /^[\q{abc|def}]$/v.test('abc')
    true
    
    ```
    
-   Set operations for character classes:
    
    ```node-repl
    > /^[\w--[a-g]]$/v.test('a')
    false
    > /^[\p{Number}--[0-9]]$/v.test('٣')
    true
    > /^[\p{RGI_Emoji}--\q{😵‍💫}]$/v.test('😵‍💫')
    false
    
    ```
    
-   Improved matching with  `/i`  if a Unicode property escape is negated via  `[^···]`
    

### New features for ArrayBuffers and SharedArrayBuffers[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#new-features-for-arraybuffers-and-sharedarraybuffers)

ArrayBuffers get two new features:

-   They can be  [resized](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_typed-arrays.html#resizing-array-buffers)  in place:
    
    ```js
    const buf = new ArrayBuffer(2, {maxByteLength: 4});
    // `typedArray` starts at offset 2
    const typedArray = new Uint8Array(buf, 2);
    assert.equal(
      typedArray.length, 0
    );
    buf.resize(4);
    assert.equal(
      typedArray.length, 2
    );
    
    ```
    
-   They get a method  `.transfer()`  for  [transferring](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_typed-arrays.html#transferring-detaching-array-buffers)  them.

SharedArrayBuffers can be resized, but they can only grow and never shrink. They are not transferrable and therefore don’t get the method  `.transfer()`  that  `ArrayBuffers`  got.

### Ensuring that strings are well-formed[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#ensuring-that-strings-are-well-formed)

Two new methods help us ensure that strings are well-formed (w.r.t.  [UTF-16](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_unicode.html#utf-16)  code units):

-   [String method  `.isWellFormed()`](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_strings.html#qref-String.prototype.isWellFormed)  checks if a JavaScript string is  _well-formed_  and does not contain any  [_lone surrogates_](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_unicode.html#unicode-lone-surrogate).
-   [String method  `.toWellFormed()`](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_strings.html#qref-String.prototype.isWellFormed)  returns a copy of the receiver where each lone surrogate is replaced with the code unit 0xFFFD (which represents the code point with the same number, whose name is “replacement character”). The result is therefore well-formed.

### `Atomics.waitAsync()`[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#atomics.waitasync())

`Atomics.waitAsync()`  lets us wait asynchronously for a change to shared memory. See  [the MDN Web Docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Atomics/waitAsync)  for more information.

## Free book on ECMAScript 2024[](https://2ality.com/2024/06/ecmascript-2024.html#free-book-on-ecmascript-2024)

My book  [“Exploring JavaScript (ES2024 Edition)”](https://exploringjs.com/js/)  is free to read online. Two chapters are especially relevant:

-   [“History and evolution of JavaScript”](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_history.html): ECMAScript vs. JavaScript, TC39, TC39 process, ECMAScript proposals, etc.
-   [“New JavaScript features”](https://exploringjs.com/js/book/ch_new-javascript-features.html#ch_new-javascript-features): What are the new features of each ECMAScript version?
```
